[Ruseau]: And it seems like a long time, like, you know, seventh grade, they do this, everything looks dandy.

[Ruseau]: If in

[Ruseau]: Later in the same seventh grade year eighth grade or ninth grade, they, they have a new addiction 10th grades a long time to wait to find out.

[Ruseau]: So, is that, what are your thoughts on that we had previously done seventh and ninth grade.

[Ruseau]: Okay, thank you.

[Ruseau]: Member Ruseau.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: So last year, our professional association adopted a new bylaw because each year the resolutions committee would put forward and school committees could put forward resolutions for MASC.

[Ruseau]: Then these would become the things that MASC would be pushing for with the legislature, their advocacy work would be centered around these resolutions.

[Ruseau]: Before last year, those resolutions just kept getting added.

[Ruseau]: So their docket of things for which they should be paying attention to was quite long.

[Ruseau]: And there was no mechanism, even if they succeeded, frankly, for them to stop pushing for it.

[Ruseau]: So last year, they adopted, we adopted, the association adopted a new bylaw that says that every three years,

[Ruseau]: any resolution just automatically will expire.

[Ruseau]: That if a member school committee wishes to reaffirm that as a priority for our association, we had to vote for it.

[Ruseau]: And then if three, I believe it's three, don't hold me to that.

[Ruseau]: If three different school committees reaffirm that the resolution should be continued as a priority,

[Ruseau]: then it will just automatically be continued to the actual conference in November, where it will be voted on.

[Ruseau]: So that's the gist of it.

[Ruseau]: The list of expiring resolutions included many more that I think we all, many of us care about.

[Ruseau]: Some of them were partially already approved.

[Ruseau]: had been partially successful.

[Ruseau]: Others were, well, these are the ones that after I looked at the list I thought were important, and I also took a kind of a pragmatic view.

[Ruseau]: Some of them were things for which I didn't necessarily think the Association

[Ruseau]: could effectively advocate for.

[Ruseau]: So that was just my opinion.

[Ruseau]: But this is the list of the ones that I thought we should reaffirm, and hopefully we can get the association to continue that.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: So it was funny that I keep my own system for keeping track of resolutions that I want to put forward, and it's got a long list.

[Ruseau]: And I try to prioritize them because there's only so much work that can actually get done at a time.

[Ruseau]: And I was cleaning up my list, and I found that I had this one sitting in there from several years ago, which I thought was very timely since we just had a new member.

[Ruseau]: This is language that is almost verbatim what everybody else has in other districts.

[Ruseau]: with the exception that there's a lot of like.

[Ruseau]: to be generic for all the various types of communities we have.

[Ruseau]: So I. Cleaned it up because in most of these in the language that was originally provided that I found it was it said the city clerk would do things that are superintendent does, and I wasn't really looking to change anything.

[Ruseau]: I was just looking to get the language to reflect what

[Ruseau]: outdated and missing some of the stuff that changed in the law.

[Ruseau]: I'll take the first one first.

[Ruseau]: So, wait, what was the first one?

[Ruseau]: How can a new member if Oh, yes.

[Ruseau]: It's a great question.

[Ruseau]: And if we were all new.

[Ruseau]: Traditionally, and again it's just a tradition that the leadership of committees are typically not new members just because there's an awful lot to learn.

[Ruseau]: but it is entirely possible, especially in Medford where everybody is up at the same time, that we could be an entirely new committee.

[Ruseau]: I think that that's not considered in the language here.

[Ruseau]: I think that we would vote for a secretary and then that person, good luck, but would have to then know all this stuff as well.

[Ruseau]: So I don't know that we can get into that because if that happens,

[Ruseau]: it's going to be very challenging for the committee anyways.

[Ruseau]: The other question though, so we have been trying to clean up our policies and not have policies contain other policies.

[Ruseau]: Right, we have a non-discrimination policy and by inserting the language all over the place, every time we change it, we effectively need to update dozens or more policies, which we never do.

[Ruseau]: So then there's like

[Ruseau]: language is outdated and wrong all over the place.

[Ruseau]: So this is not an attempt to suggest that a school committee member would not be following that.

[Ruseau]: On the other hand, it's also important to note that elections are elections, and that if a school committee member wants to violate all of our policies and wants to violate the law, there's literally nothing that can be done about it.

[Ruseau]: So having meaningless language

[Ruseau]: is something I'm opposed to because less is more.

[Ruseau]: So, I think having language that is enforceable is important.

[Ruseau]: So, thank you.

[Ruseau]: The current policy already actually says that this is supposed to come to the secretary.

[Ruseau]: And I believe that's language directly out of the law.

[Ruseau]: I don't want this, it doesn't make sense to me that it would come to the secretary, like the keeper of our records by law is me, but by practice is the superintendent.

[Ruseau]: And I think that's the case in virtually every school committee there is, because the secretary is not a nine to five full-time job.

[Ruseau]: But I think,

[Ruseau]: And I don't know if there's anything in the statute about should we be delegating authority to the superintendent or not, but that's, that's the way it, I mean, this is current language, and

[Ruseau]: It doesn't make sense to me.

[Ruseau]: And if nobody ever comes and gives this to me, I'm perfectly fine with that.

[Ruseau]: Nobody has ever done it.

[Ruseau]: I'm not aware.

[Ruseau]: And I wouldn't know what to do with it if you gave it to me.

[Ruseau]: But I think the superintendent has her office acts as the keeper of records, even though like I take the votes and that's because of the secretary's role.

[Ruseau]: So I certainly understand that it's,

[Ruseau]: I think it's just weird.

[Ruseau]: But I think the other thing, though, is that in Massachusetts, while school committees, for the most part, there's different sizes, but they're still fairly the same kind of idea.

[Ruseau]: Districts are not.

[Ruseau]: There's regional school districts, and they're very different kinds of districts.

[Ruseau]: some regional districts are literally municipalities like a city.

[Ruseau]: Meanwhile, we're not in this municipality as a school district.

[Ruseau]: So I think there's some other weirdness.

[Ruseau]: And I think whenever they write these laws, they want to make universal.

[Ruseau]: Things get frankly, muddy is an understatement.

[Ruseau]: So I hear your point, but it's current.

[Ruseau]: That's the language to say the oath is with the clerk.

[Ruseau]: So the one of the most common things we hear about is you know we have the students whether they're high school students are tough students.

[Ruseau]: And the ratio of 10 students per adult, for the most part, we cannot include those people in our ratios because students have finals and they can't show up or tough students go on spring break and we can't close the program down or tell parents your kids can't come to the afterschool program because we don't have enough adults.

[Ruseau]: So I think that's an important, when we list all the different kinds of people that we have working,

[Ruseau]: Frankly, there's a whole lot of them that we can't include in the numbers for our ratios and I don't think there is a solution we're not going to actually get any tough students or or Medford high students who will be like no no I under no circumstances while I miss work like that's doesn't make any sense we want our high school students to be students first.

[Ruseau]: and tough students probably want a break when they have breaks.

[Ruseau]: So I think that's just an important thing to repeat yet again.

[Ruseau]: the union or the unit, there isn't actually one number for the different units or unions.

[Ruseau]: And I'm fine with that.

[Ruseau]: take a non union group of employees and tie their increases to a union because essentially that union ends up negotiating for these non members.

[Ruseau]: And I know that like we're at where I've worked at Mass General Brigham.

[Ruseau]: you know, the nurses at Mass General Hospital are non-unionized and the nurses at the Brigham are.

[Ruseau]: And so the Mass General nurses just get whatever the Brigham nurses are getting.

[Ruseau]: They just move lockstep, except the Mass General nurses didn't have to pay union dues.

[Ruseau]: So I do just want us to get clarification before we would make a motion on that piece.

[Ruseau]: Oh, it is?

[Ruseau]: Oh, well then, frankly, that's common in NEDS.

[Ruseau]: I didn't make it up.

[Ruseau]: Okay.

[Ruseau]: It's such a great idea.

[Ruseau]: I assumed you made it up.

[Ruseau]: Okay, well, if that's common in NEDS, and I definitely like that, can you just find out whether they typically tie it to the paras or the teachers?

[Ruseau]: I know a lot of districts, the teachers and the paras are in the same union.

[Ruseau]: So because they're not in Medford, we may have to just pick one.

[Ruseau]: The negotiated increases in their contracts are typically very similar, although paras recently have had

[Ruseau]: very big jumps because we wanted to fix that scale.

[Ruseau]: So like when we did a 25% increase in the last pair of contract, if we had done this then, you might have a financial problem in your program if we just 25% increases across the board for your staff.

[Ruseau]: So we do have to be a little more thoughtful on that.

[Ruseau]: That's...

[Ruseau]: That's my one concern there.

[Ruseau]: And then that was somehow was all my questions, because I've asked them over and over through previous years.

[Ruseau]: So I do want to thank you for explaining that lottery stuff, because while I understood the lottery in general, the whole, the incoming kindergartner getting through, and even though the other sibling is still on the wait list, that makes a lot of sense.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I wouldn't want to have to be the family that's in that situation, but at the same time,

[Ruseau]: It's one less problem for families that can make that work.

[Ruseau]: But it's unfortunate we don't have the space to be like, you're kindergarten again, so we're going to make room for the third grader.

[Ruseau]: But that's not how it works, because once they're in, they're not leaving.

[Ruseau]: So thank you for all your work.

[Ruseau]: I know it's never ending.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I did have one more question I forgot to ask earlier.

[Ruseau]: not not you, but when we've talked about, you know, whether we change middle school to an elementary school and we've had kind of off the record conversations around what can we do around our challenges around some schools being very oversubscribed and other schools being well the mistook having a much lower population of students rezoning is a temporary problem that just essentially

[Ruseau]: kicks the ball a few years and people move to different places and then you have the same problem again.

[Ruseau]: the regulations which you know all that stuff and I don't.

[Ruseau]: So if the DEI office says, I would change the wording on this and I would change the wording on that, and we've just approved this wording, then we're having another meeting to approve the recommendations or not approve the recommendations of DEI office, which by the way, might also be an uncomfortable situation where we're like, we like this wording, we use this in education, and the DEI office says we should use this wording.

[Ruseau]: I don't particularly have an interest in that kind of like, well, who's right?

[Ruseau]: Which way should we go?

[Ruseau]: We can't call the DEI office to come to our meeting and provide input.

[Ruseau]: They don't, they're completely separate part of the government.

[Ruseau]: So that's sort of my concern, not at all with what the content of a DEI office reviewing it would be.

[Ruseau]: Yes, I mean, there's also this very uncomfortable thing that we aren't talking about that I think happens in circles in government when we're having these conversations where we're like, we want to include people whose primary language may not be English or they may not speak English at all.

[Ruseau]: And I hate to use the word reality because it sounds like

[Ruseau]: I don't know.

[Ruseau]: So if we couldn't conclude this process in 270 days because we were translating on the fly in every meeting the entire conversation going on,

[Ruseau]: would we be able to finish this process?

[Ruseau]: And that's an important question.

[Ruseau]: So it really gets to the root of the fact that government isn't designed for inclusion, 100%.

[Ruseau]: It's designed around an assumption that everybody's speaking English.

[Ruseau]: how we would want to handle that.

[Ruseau]: If we have an applicant who is an expert in all these things and we want this person to be on there, we're going to have to have a conversation around funding because we're going to have to fund an interpreter for all these meetings and all these documents.

[Ruseau]: Then we're going to have to sit down and have a hard look about how much additional time would we be required to complete the process if we were on the fly

[Ruseau]: I mean, I don't think we run any zoom meetings that I'm aware of in the city where every single thing is being interpreted for a participant of a board into another language.

[Ruseau]: And it would all have to be interpreted for them to be a proper participant in the board.

[Ruseau]: So it's a very challenging.

[Ruseau]: thing that I think, I wish there was an easier answer, but I think that's sort of the elephant in the room on this issue.

[Ruseau]: I just worry about how we would actually accomplish that.

[Ruseau]: You know, this $1.1 million appropriation, that just went back to the city, and then in FY24, the appropriation was 250,000.

[Ruseau]: Neither of those numbers together cover

[Ruseau]: the expense is what I understand, correct?

[Ruseau]: you won't remember any of this, but on January 6th of 2020, we got our FY 2019 budget close out, and it lists what we budgeted, what we spent, and the differences, and it's sideways, so I can't really go through it too easily.

[Ruseau]: And I don't believe we have received such a report since then, so I don't know.

[Ruseau]: That means nothing for FY20, FY21, FY22, FY23.

[Ruseau]: We have never seen a closeout that shows us that we budgeted $5,000 and spent $180,000 or whatever it is.

[Ruseau]: And some of that is that it takes so long to close out because the systems are not, we're not using Munis and we're just using

[Ruseau]: inappropriately outdated systems.

[Ruseau]: But I think that if you have a closeout report for any of those years, I certainly would be grateful because I think when the committee is looking at our budget proposal, and we see a line item for 5,000, and we see that last year the line item was 5,000, the rational person sees that and says, oh, okay, that should be fine, right?

[Ruseau]: But if we also could have a report at the same time that says, no, we budgeted 5,000,

[Ruseau]: The superintendent's budget says $5,000, but it was $160,000 in spending.

[Ruseau]: Well, that's a major conversation.

[Ruseau]: And I would hope the committee can have that by the time we do the budget.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: And I just have one more question and then I'll let my colleagues jump in.

[Ruseau]: Looking at the FY20 budget, which nobody has in front of them but me, but near the very end of the budget book, and this is something that Medford has been doing for a very long time,

[Ruseau]: there is a long list of positions that are not in any way, shape or form anything other than normal operations.

[Ruseau]: Let's see, we have a director, we have secretaries, we have teachers, we have tech people, another director, another director, some paras, all of which are actually regular operating normal part of running a school district.

[Ruseau]: And $1.85 million worth of staff is actually listed as being on grants from revolving, the grants of course is different, but much of this is just from revolving accounts.

[Ruseau]: And so I'm aware having talked to other finance directors like the one at the short collaborative, that this is very unusual.

[Ruseau]: I won't go any further than that.

[Ruseau]: But my question to you is this,

[Ruseau]: How does, if there's such a thing as a normal district, if we put all of these people on the budget, which we should do, and then we have these revolving accounts that build up funds, how does a normal district dispose of those funds?

[Ruseau]: Do they just, at the end of the year, like, hey, we have 1.5 extra million dollars from afterschool or whatever the number is, do we, we don't just let that build up forever or become a,

[Ruseau]: private checkbook for the superintendent to do fun things in the district.

[Ruseau]: Do we write a check and transfer it back to the city so that it can become part of the budget.

[Ruseau]: How does, what does a district normally do with all that.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: You know, when I'm looking at this, there's this spreadsheet you gave us.

[Ruseau]: All these numbers are of course are concerning, but there is a general up in addition to the running out of paper thing there's this.

[Ruseau]: drumbeat that we don't have substitutes.

[Ruseau]: And somehow in FY23, we budgeted a quarter of a million dollars, but spent almost $900,000 on substitutes, which is hard to do if we don't have substitutes.

[Ruseau]: So I don't know where that money is going, or if there's a perception that just because there was a day without a substitute, that there are no substitutes.

[Ruseau]: I know that generalizing can happen, but this number does not tell the story that the community and some teachers definitely are telling, that there's never any substitutes.

[Ruseau]: How do you spend a million dollars

[Ruseau]: on substitutes if there aren't any, or 900,000.

[Ruseau]: But we appropriated, again, a totally inappropriate number.

[Ruseau]: FY23 was not a, quote, pandemic year.

[Ruseau]: And so, like the previous year where there was lots of people out for

[Ruseau]: you know, because everybody was testing.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I know the pandemic really is, you know, some people would say it's not over and I can't disagree with that.

[Ruseau]: But, you know, to appropriate only even less in FY 24, and then to already be projected to spend twice the appropriation that I just

[Ruseau]: I'm confused about why we're even trying to appropriate, why are we putting numbers down in our budget book at all on a lot of these things they're just made up numbers to squeeze into a number we've been handed on a slip of paper from the city.

[Ruseau]: But to be fair, some of these numbers were in our budget book, before we got that appropriation, you know, the $5,000 I looked back in some of the older budgets, my very first budget, it said $2,000.

[Ruseau]: The next one that said $30,000.

[Ruseau]: So it looked like somebody was like, hey, we probably should go up.

[Ruseau]: Now, of course, I don't have actuals.

[Ruseau]: So I don't know what the actuals were.

[Ruseau]: But

[Ruseau]: You know this substitute line though and there's another story in here because we're definitely spending a lot of money on substitutes and it's worth noting we pay less for substitutes than most other districts, so it's even more people and and substitute hours that are happening.

[Ruseau]: Thank you, that's actually, I would never have guessed that that line meant that.

[Ruseau]: Is there any, you have plenty of work on your plate, but is there any way you can divide this line item in the future so that charges that when we're paying teachers for lost prep times, that that's a separate line item than substitutes we're hiring in?

[Ruseau]: Because certainly like, they seem like totally like, can we get enough substitutes, this line item,

[Ruseau]: tells a very different story than what it turns out to be accurate.

[Ruseau]: And I would really like to know that, especially when we go into the next teacher contract, like, you know, how much are we actually spending on last prep period, which right now I don't think we could easily tell, at least not from here, maybe in the budget.

[Ruseau]: Right, thank you.

[Ruseau]: And then, I think you touched on the security wages already, but

[Ruseau]: I'm just, is a lot of this expense related to things like the bathrooms and the, you haven't been here long enough for all of our multi-year debate, discussion, community conversation on the safety of our bathrooms and stuff like that.

[Ruseau]: But when we're paying administrators or anybody else to monitor bathrooms,

[Ruseau]: assuming we're paying them, I think we are.

[Ruseau]: Thank you, I know you said that earlier, I've already forgotten, sorry.

[Ruseau]: No problem.

[Ruseau]: And then I did have, what was my question?

[Ruseau]: You already answered that already.

[Ruseau]: In the building repairs, as Member Graham pointed out, we just keep budgeting for a number that doesn't make any sense, especially with an old building like the high school, but then it turns out all the other buildings as well.

[Ruseau]: It does this include expenses when the city donate donates when the city covers capital expenses like you know rekeying doors or.

[Ruseau]: And this is the position we have been in year after year.

[Ruseau]: $500,000, we're going to budget 100,000 and just see what happens.

[Ruseau]: 150,000, building repairs is $150,000.

[Ruseau]: Each year that I looked at, and I can say quite confidently, there has never been a year where it was anywhere close to that.

[Ruseau]: So that's why I'm not following the advisory committee policy we have, because it's not an advisory committee.

[Ruseau]: An advisory committee doesn't actually make decisions.

[Ruseau]: They make decisions, well, they make decisions, but then they come to us and then we make the decision.

[Ruseau]: And so managing a group of that size is certainly a challenge, but even if that wasn't a challenge, we have to also acknowledge that what we're asking for in the commitment to be on this committee

[Ruseau]: is as much work as it is to be a school committee member, probably more.

[Ruseau]: I mean, it's many hours a week of uncompensated labor and it's an open meeting.

[Ruseau]: If a quorum doesn't show up, we don't keep moving along in our process to getting a new high school until that quorum can show up.

[Ruseau]: So the commitment that we're asking whoever does end up being on this, it's not a garden club.

[Ruseau]: We're asking for a shocking amount of unpaid labor

[Ruseau]: and a commitment, and as Member Graham pointed out, like the committee will probably change over the course of five to seven years.

[Ruseau]: So that's normal and not surprising, but we will have to be very careful that we, you know, if we decided we wanted to have several students and they're voting members, but if they don't show up and then suddenly there's not a quorum, whatever the agenda was, it's not happening.

[Ruseau]: So I want to know what that MIAA heat protocol looks like.

[Ruseau]: Is it more conservative, less conservative than our heat protocol?

[Ruseau]: If it's less conservative,

[Ruseau]: that I think we need a conversation around that because the science around what's healthy and all that other stuff isn't different for students that happen to be participating in sports.

[Ruseau]: And we see that every single year in this country where it's like, you gotta play your football in a well, you know, and with coaches and other places, not here necessarily, but coaches that don't let you take water breaks

[Ruseau]: really some pretty egregious stuff that I'm not suggesting we have here, but whenever I hear about another protocol that is not mentioned, I'm nervous that it's not aligned with ours.

[Ruseau]: And if it's not aligned with ours, we need a real conversation around

[Ruseau]: Great, thank you.

[Ruseau]: And then there's a reference to our policy EBCD emergency closings.

[Ruseau]: I do like a couple of the other things that aren't relevant, so I won't make us stay here all night long, but thank you.

[Ruseau]: I appreciate you getting this going.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I just looked up the average length of heat waves.

[Ruseau]: We're up to about four days now.

[Ruseau]: The only time you will not be able to replace your 10,000

[Ruseau]: water bottles is during a heat wave.

[Ruseau]: So we don't need 10,000 on hand, we need 40,000 on hand.

[Ruseau]: And God, I have no idea where you're going to put 40,000 bottles of water.

[Ruseau]: We'll pretend that there's no environmental impact to that for the moment.

[Ruseau]: But if you have 10,000, then you have to cancel school the next three days of the heat wave, because you have no water.

[Ruseau]: So, you know, if that's part of the plan to have water bottles on hand, which I

[Ruseau]: think might be worth talking about because, I mean, we're not assuming there's not gonna be water in the school functionally.

[Ruseau]: If the water doesn't work in the schools, I assume we have to cancel anyways, because you can't flush the toilets.

[Ruseau]: So, you know, that 10,000, that two bottles of water per person per day, if that's something that we really wanna stick with, we have to get a lot more water if there's really a strong rationale behind that.

[Ruseau]: And I don't know the conversations that went into why, but, you know.

[Ruseau]: No, yeah, I mean, I okay.

[Ruseau]: Yeah, I mean, yeah, there is that but also like, you know, we don't want to have day to be like, well, we used up our water supply.

[Ruseau]: So now we our plan is that we have to now cancel school because we don't have water.

[Ruseau]: So, and then the other thing was,

[Ruseau]: You were mentioning, you know, the misting devices and the things that you would presumably set up rental agreements with.

[Ruseau]: I assume when we do those rental agreements, we're going to make sure that those rental agreements include something that sort of gives us, you know, I assume that they don't have 100 of these things at every rental place.

[Ruseau]: And when there's a heat wave coming,

[Ruseau]: other people are going to be looking for them too.

[Ruseau]: So like, we need to make sure that our rental agreement isn't just that this is going to be our price, but that we'll get first dibs on them.

[Ruseau]: Because, again, having plans for things that then are not going to actually be available is not a spot anybody wants to be in.

[Ruseau]: And then for the fans, you know, not that I want to spend a million dollars on fans.

[Ruseau]: But if the backup plan for

[Ruseau]: the outside schools or the elementary and the middle schools is to use fans if the air conditioning isn't working.

[Ruseau]: Well, then we need to have purchased enough fans for the entire high school.

[Ruseau]: And then at least one of those other schools, if we assume one of them is possibly gonna go offline from air conditioning, it's a lot of fans.

[Ruseau]: And I just, some, I mean, aside from the costs, like there's the storage, there's the distribution, there's the,

[Ruseau]: build a new high school, we're probably not going to have the kind of massive amounts of space laying around to store stuff.

[Ruseau]: So, I mean, some of these things are perfectly logical, but they're also

[Ruseau]: in the actual implementation things that I'm wondering how they'll really work out.

[Ruseau]: If I may,

[Ruseau]: I don't for a second doubt the intent of anyone on this particular point, but I would say that it is unlikely in the next two years for that to be a reality.

[Ruseau]: I mean, the millions of dollars that have to be spent to make that a reality, not to mention then the procurement, then the actual doing the work, that's not happening this summer.

[Ruseau]: So, you know, we will have a heat wave this year.

[Ruseau]: There's like a 0% chance we're not gonna have a heat wave.

[Ruseau]: Um, it's maybe 0% is not the right amount.

[Ruseau]: But, um, so I'm just worried because, you know, we started the last school year in a bad spot.

[Ruseau]: And frankly, I mean, for the new members, you haven't quite experienced it yet.

[Ruseau]: But most of us are pretty sick and tired of the same conversations about the fact that we had all summer long, and we didn't notice that the air conditioning was broken at an elementary school.

[Ruseau]: I'm

[Ruseau]: really tired of that.

[Ruseau]: So while I understand we want to buy enough fans just for the high school, I want to buy enough fans to at least have one of the other schools not have functional air conditioning because I fully believe that's what's going to happen in the next couple of years.

[Ruseau]: I'd like to be wrong.

[Ruseau]: Right.

[Ruseau]: And I just want also sort of a clarifying question.

[Ruseau]: So, I mean, I believe Medford does not usually do delayed start because of the number of days of actual education we provide is the minimum the state allows for other districts to have like 184,

[Ruseau]: that pay their teachers for 189 days like Cambridge.

[Ruseau]: If they do that, it's a different conversation.

[Ruseau]: So we don't do delayed starts, but if we need to close an elementary school, we close the district, is that correct?

[Ruseau]: Okay, since it's not, it doesn't sound like it's a desi thing.

[Ruseau]: It's just a financial thing.

[Ruseau]: Then I'm not gonna be all worried about that.

[Ruseau]: But okay, thank you so much.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Thinking about that quadrant chart, are teachers looking at that?

[Ruseau]: Yeah.

[Ruseau]: So a student that might have a whole pile of relative strengths and a major weakness could show up in that top right quadrant.

[Ruseau]: And if I'm a teacher and I've got a bunch of students that I've got to focus on, I'm not clicking on that student because I have only so many hours in a day.

[Ruseau]: How do we make sure that because this one data point is a student,

[Ruseau]: How do we make sure that we don't have, I'm sure when teachers are receiving students into the middle school, into an algebra class or something, and then they find out that, why does little Johnny not know how to do this very basic thing, even though he got great grades and knew all these other concepts?

[Ruseau]: It feels like that's a story we hear about when kids go off to college and they can't do some, frankly, basic things.

[Ruseau]: And I just feel like this,

[Ruseau]: average as a single data point for a student can seriously hide major deficiencies, or is that average not really an average, but it's some kind of other NWEA map calculation that prevents that?

[Ruseau]: It helps, but you said something just now that was sort of partially my point.

[Ruseau]: Teachers are, there's only so many hours in a day for teachers.

[Ruseau]: We just heard that at the Andrews, 2 3rds or 70% of kids made the honor roll.

[Ruseau]: I'll go on a limb and bet that means a lot of kids, when we looked at this quadrant chart, were in that big green section for, let's pick math.

[Ruseau]: And what I'm worried about is it's quite reasonable for teachers to be focusing on students in these other quadrants more.

[Ruseau]: These are the students that are performing.

[Ruseau]: These are the students that are growing.

[Ruseau]: You've got so many hours or time in your class.

[Ruseau]: Who are you going to put more attention on?

[Ruseau]: You're going to put it on the students who need more help, which is rational and reasonable.

[Ruseau]: But these are one dot representing the students.

[Ruseau]: You could be a rock star with these huge scores in some areas of math and then have some major deficits that are just not relevant to what's going on.

[Ruseau]: You can just skate through with your A and sitting in the green.

[Ruseau]: And then when you go up to the next grade, this happened to one of my children who went into an honors math class.

[Ruseau]: And it was because of the pandemic.

[Ruseau]: It wasn't for any other reason.

[Ruseau]: But there were whole sections of math for which the student couldn't perform, none of them, frankly.

[Ruseau]: And while that's a different kind of situation because it was most of the students, I'm just worried about how if you have only so much time in the day and you're looking at this quadrant chart as your starting point for where to focus, you're not clicking on your students that are high performing, high growth already.

[Ruseau]: And this is an average that will mean that you have, we put a billionaire in this room, average all of our incomes.

[Ruseau]: Things look great.

[Ruseau]: Those are not, we're not all making $100 million a year.

[Ruseau]: So I just worry about the work that averages can really cause skewing within the individual student as well.

[Ruseau]: And maybe there's somebody that makes sure that every single one of these students was inspected at some regularity from this chart.

[Ruseau]: I don't know if that's your team or the principals, or does this pop out a report that says, hey, this teacher in math, there was never once did anybody inspect this report for this student this year.

[Ruseau]: That's after you've clicked the student, though.

[Ruseau]: I doubt that.

[Ruseau]: That does help.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I think that sometimes we've heard tonight that it was the individual student was the strength of a lot of this reporting.

[Ruseau]: And now we're kind of back up to the middle of the curriculum.

[Ruseau]: Yes.

[Ruseau]: And obviously, I think that that makes complete sense what you're describing, and that's great to hear.

[Ruseau]: But if all this testing is about the individual student, then I'm interested in knowing that every individual student's report is looked at by every single teacher.

[Ruseau]: Yes.

[Ruseau]: no matter whether the student is sitting up there in the top corner green and the teacher has 20 other students in the bottom quadrant who need a lot of time and focus, because a kid could not know how to deal with money, for instance.

[Ruseau]: One of my children, math was fine, but then when the report came out, turns out they didn't know anything about money, which for those of us that can just, well, that's just percentages.

[Ruseau]: I just worry about, and I think the teachers would worry about receiving students with major gaps that are missed because the report is an average for the whole individual student, which is not, you know, it's not how you teach new concepts in math in particular.

[Ruseau]: You need those basic concepts, all of them.

[Ruseau]: There's no like optional ones.

[Ruseau]: And so I'll stop because I've gone on too long, thank you.

[Ruseau]: Okay.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: My thinking on this is that if we're passing a policy after a deadline,

[Ruseau]: that we simply set the date for when it becomes effective, because I'm not really interested in having all of this.

[Ruseau]: I mean, it's the principals aren't running around changing these, the site councils are.

[Ruseau]: So I don't think it's reasonable for us to, a week before or a week after site councils have submitted their proposed changes for us to be just making changes to policy.

[Ruseau]: Obviously we can make changes to policy at any time, but I think that when our policy changes,

[Ruseau]: are going to affect the handbook, we should just consider whether or not, can this just wait another year?

[Ruseau]: It's not like if we wait another year,

[Ruseau]: There's, you know, for the most part, those kinds of things are not the end of the world.

[Ruseau]: I mean, the bullying policy was an example that's very, very different because it was so substantial.

[Ruseau]: And this is a great example of what we just did.

[Ruseau]: But a lot of the policy changes we're making are not things that if they waited another year to be in a handbook that anybody would even,

[Ruseau]: be bent out of shape about.

[Ruseau]: So I'm not so much concerned about the cost of printing, although, you know, money's tight.

[Ruseau]: But I am concerned about the work of the site councils.

[Ruseau]: And there's also an important thing about the handbook, though.

[Ruseau]: There are sections of the handbook that are

[Ruseau]: sort of inherited from the district.

[Ruseau]: They're the same in every single handbook.

[Ruseau]: Site councils don't even really have a say in them, things such as things that come from the law.

[Ruseau]: So whether or not the change would affect site council work, I think is something to be considered.

[Ruseau]: And I certainly think that

[Ruseau]: As a chair of the policy subcommittee.

[Ruseau]: This is not something I had thought through.

[Ruseau]: So I think that is something to consider in our procedures around policy adoption to be like

[Ruseau]: you know, sort of a checkbox, does this affect handbooks?

[Ruseau]: And if so, when should it go into effect?

[Ruseau]: Because that's an easy thing to consider rather than setting some arbitrary date, because a lot of times policies come up because something's happening and we can't wait.

[Ruseau]: So knowing the impact of the change, I think, is something we can just put right into our procedures.

[Ruseau]: I need language that.

[Ruseau]: I just also want to remind us from a security perspective that the high school must be unlocked and open for these meetings.

[Ruseau]: These are public meetings, just like these.

[Ruseau]: We can't have locked doors, so we'll have to plan the security around that, unless we don't have a quorum of members, in which case it's just a meeting.

[Ruseau]: So that's important to remember.

[Ruseau]: When posting the agenda, if more than three of us show up, none of us are speaking about anything related to policy, unless it's already on the agenda.

[Ruseau]: So I just, my biggest concern about these meetings, which I obviously want to hear from the students, is I don't want each of these meetings to be a series of open meeting law violations, because nobody really wants to deal with those.

[Ruseau]: So somebody will have to plan the effort around

[Ruseau]: making our high school open at 230 when there's clubs and all the other stuff.

[Ruseau]: Because I assume we're going to have them there, it doesn't make sense to cart the students over here, that doesn't make any sense.

[Ruseau]: So I just want to make sure those logistics are worked out, rather than on the 17th or the 15th of November, when we sit down and we have a quorum.

[Ruseau]: And then there's a locked door because that's just not gonna be acceptable.

[Ruseau]: It's also against, it's a violation, so.

[Ruseau]: Sorry, I mean, if we're speaking at all, then if there's four of us, then it is a meeting.

[Ruseau]: an official meeting that will have an agenda posted following open meeting law.

[Ruseau]: If we all swear to sit silently and listen or nod and be jovial and not engage in a single item of a policy for which we have authority, then I don't think that's a meeting, that's just four or more of us happen to be in the same place.

[Ruseau]: Of course, yes.

[Ruseau]: An agenda, though, can be just that we're having a meeting and we're showing up and we're going to listen to the students.

[Ruseau]: That's an agenda, an agenda that has items such as we're going to talk about food service or we're going to talk about this.

[Ruseau]: Those are different kinds of agendas.

[Ruseau]: They're both agendas.

[Ruseau]: And Medford has a long history of showing up to talk about whatever anybody wants to talk about.

[Ruseau]: And that's not how open meeting law works.

[Ruseau]: And I just don't want to be the person sitting there silently because I don't want to violate open meeting law on a topic that I care greatly about.

[Ruseau]: That's my biggest beef, frankly.

[Ruseau]: If other members feel comfortable ignoring that, that's up to them.

[Ruseau]: But I don't want to sit here silently looking like a jerk because I won't say anything on a topic that's not on the agenda for which we have authority.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: If I have a 10 hour day, I sometimes I'm like, this day won't end.

[Ruseau]: Okay.

[Ruseau]: Do you lose vacation days each year that you're allotted in your contract, but you can't actually figure out how to take because you're so busy?

[Ruseau]: Okay, thank you.

[Ruseau]: I just, I think these are important considerations when we consider adding work to you, because I was part of the committee that hired you.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, there are many different views on what we people expect from a chief executive some people expect a chief executive to be shackled to their job, and not sleep.

[Ruseau]: frankly, a lot of chief executives do that, and they're proud of it.

[Ruseau]: And Medford had a history of a superintendent who worked 12, 16 hour days, six days a week, and that worked for Medford at the time and for that superintendent.

[Ruseau]: But when we were hiring, we were very clear, I was very clear and I think the room was clear, that we were looking for somebody who had some concept of work-life balance and was actually going to be a person who could have a life outside of Medford Public Schools.

[Ruseau]: And so when I hear about you can't take the vacation that you're allotted in your contract and you don't get paid for it either, it just vanishes and you,

[Ruseau]: are working, you know, I mean, there's the whole, you know, working smarter, not harder, all that stuff.

[Ruseau]: But there are limits to working smarter and not harder.

[Ruseau]: When your boss, which is us, piles more stuff on that we expect only you to do, not to delegate, but only you to do.

[Ruseau]: You know, it's quite reasonable in my mind for us to keep piling work on and for you to delegate it.

[Ruseau]: But if we pile work on and we say, it is only,

[Ruseau]: Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent who may perform these duties, then I think it's reasonable for us to consider whether or not we're being in, you know, excessive.

[Ruseau]: And so when we talk about, you know,

[Ruseau]: I went to many PTO meetings, not many, some PTO meetings when my kids were in elementary school, the principal was always there and I thought that worked.

[Ruseau]: And I mean, has anybody asked principals if they want the superintendent sitting in on their meetings?

[Ruseau]: I don't know.

[Ruseau]: And I don't mean this to be anything about any specific thing tonight, but I do think that, you know, we want you here at eight o'clock in the morning and we want you here at 10 o'clock at night or nine o'clock at night.

[Ruseau]: And I just think we need to think about what we're expecting and asking of one human being.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, we don't put it everywhere in our policies, but we often say the superintendent will do this.

[Ruseau]: And we decided a while ago that we wouldn't every single time say, or his or her delegate, because that becomes obnoxious to see that written everywhere.

[Ruseau]: But when we are asking the superintendent to do something, most of the time, I mean, I'm expecting the superintendent to delegate that stuff, not to figure out how to find more hours in a day.

[Ruseau]: And so whenever we ask for things, we're explicitly saying the superintendent is the person that must do it.

[Ruseau]: I think we need to like,

[Ruseau]: get out a piece of paper and start figuring out how much are we asking only the superintendent to do.

[Ruseau]: It just concerns me greatly, because there is no time when I can't talk to you, or, and you know, you'll call me or something about like some agenda item, and you're not at home working from home you're still at the office and it's long past rush hour.

[Ruseau]: I just have a lot of concern about what this looks like.

[Ruseau]: And someday if we have to hire another superintendent, they're gonna look and say, well, would you last superintendent have to, I don't want a 93 hour a week work, because guess what?

[Ruseau]: The salary sounds great to folks who see the contract, but then when you start dividing it up by the number of hours, it starts to not look so good.

[Ruseau]: So I'm just deeply concerned about how many goals we are having.

[Ruseau]: if we expect those goals to be met exclusively by you personally rather than your ability to delegate them.

[Ruseau]: And that just sort of a statement about concern.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I just want to agree vehemently with member Hays on the survey.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, when I read the results, you know, just going to pick an example here, about 40% of respondents agreed that students at the high school were teased or picked on about their physical or intellectual disability.

[Ruseau]: Everybody agrees the right percentage is zero, we would love to see that no student thinks that that happens.

[Ruseau]: But what I would want to know.

[Ruseau]: in figuring out where to focus a limited amount of resources and time is, how does that compare to other school systems with other high school people in it?

[Ruseau]: I mean, I don't like this 40%, but if you told me that the average high school it was 70%, I would be like,

[Ruseau]: Well, that's kind of very disturbing.

[Ruseau]: But I would also then say, is this the right place to first focus, considering that we can't focus on everything at once?

[Ruseau]: And there are other kinds of questions, for instance, where if 10% of students said something, it might cause everybody to panic and be like, that should be a 1%.

[Ruseau]: You know, so 10%, 40%, 2%, those things don't really mean anything without any context of what is it like in a typical high school?

[Ruseau]: We can all agree that we want these, you know, 0% of our students to believe that this kind of thing, like picking on somebody because of their physical intellectual disability, there's no question what the right number is, zero.

[Ruseau]: But if the average high school has 70% in our area,

[Ruseau]: which would be horrible.

[Ruseau]: But we had another area where it was 10% 10% of our students said something is happening, but in a typical high school it's one or 2%, like, without that information.

[Ruseau]: All we have to go on is our own sense of, we agree, this is bad.

[Ruseau]: We should focus on this.

[Ruseau]: But we don't, we can go through all of these questions and we can, without any question, there's gonna be no disagreement here that 40% should be 0% on this question.

[Ruseau]: you know, 10% should be 80% on this question.

[Ruseau]: Like there's not gonna be any question, but whether or not, which of these areas actually require our focus when there's only so much focus to give, without the other districts, the common survey that is used elsewhere to compare, I do feel like we're comparing to ourselves, which is fine.

[Ruseau]: But there's only so many hours in a day and I just do feel like that that that is missing from this, regardless of this, the design of the guesses in the know that you know the strongly agrees and strongly disagrees, even if all that wasn't a problem without the same questions being comparable to other districts.

[Ruseau]: It feels very challenging to know which

[Ruseau]: is the most important thing to focus on, but obviously not one thing.

[Ruseau]: And I just don't think we can get that unless we do go with the standardized survey that other people use.

[Ruseau]: Sort of a couple of answers to that.

[Ruseau]: Let me put this other thing that's causing my learning a couple answers there.

[Ruseau]: naming convention, numbering convention, if you will, is these letters.

[Ruseau]: And then you can see these dashes, where essentially, these are pieces that have been brought out into their own quote policy.

[Ruseau]: But

[Ruseau]: Your point is, of course, very accurate.

[Ruseau]: Like we used to, I don't know if anybody remembers, but maybe a year ago, we had what was called a school attorney policy and we renamed it.

[Ruseau]: I mean, because the law required a school attorney policy, but we're pretty sure nobody was coming for us if we renamed it to make it make sense that it was the district attorneys or the school committee's attorneys.

[Ruseau]: So I think we can probably get away with renaming it.

[Ruseau]: if it's not going to cause problems down the line where, you know, people are like, we have to have a wellness policy.

[Ruseau]: I mean, we can literally put it in the language somewhere that, you know, if there's a legal reference that says school districts will have a quote wellness policy, then we put that in the legal references.

[Ruseau]: And I think that's fine.

[Ruseau]: But whether they're all in one giant policy or in sections, I think we can break them up into sections.

[Ruseau]: So that's my take.

[Ruseau]: I said there were two things I wanted to talk about on that, and I've already forgotten what the other one was.

[Ruseau]: Great.

[Ruseau]: I think this report is not interpreting the data correctly.

[Ruseau]: We received the raw data as well.

[Ruseau]: Under cultural awareness and action, the questions were students at this school are teased or picked on about their race or ethnicity.

[Ruseau]: And 31% of our students said they agreed with that.

[Ruseau]: So the actual

[Ruseau]: Favorability would be 69, not 31.

[Ruseau]: It's more favorable that that is not true.

[Ruseau]: Correct.

[Ruseau]: We do not want more kids teasing and picking on students about race or ethnicity.

[Ruseau]: And the same is for the other question in that category, which says, students at this school are teased or picked on about their cultural background or religion. 7%

[Ruseau]: 69% of our students said that is not true.

[Ruseau]: So whether the question is a positive or a negative, we've in this report, we've just taken the top two and given it the favorability.

[Ruseau]: If we look at the end, we have a question like, my teachers often connect what I am learning to life outside the classroom.

[Ruseau]: And 54% of our students said that was true.

[Ruseau]: And that's a 54% favorability.

[Ruseau]: We want more of that, not less.

[Ruseau]: When we look at the question about the one I was just reading, we do not want more students to say that students are teased and picked on.

[Ruseau]: So the word favorability implies that's what we want, right?

[Ruseau]: Favorability does not mean you want more of what's favorable.

[Ruseau]: And that is listed in the red.

[Ruseau]: I think this,

[Ruseau]: this graphic that's showing areas for growth.

[Ruseau]: Well, first of all, everything's sort of an area for growth.

[Ruseau]: But if you look at student strength, school belonging, the questions are in a positive.

[Ruseau]: So that isn't wrong.

[Ruseau]: I'm just saying that the way the questions are formulated, the data is not being interpreted based on how the question is being asked.

[Ruseau]: I mean, you ask the same question, a positive and a negative, and you get the same answers, that would be a very different and concerning thing.

[Ruseau]: So I'm not sure that the report that you're presenting is reflected in the data that we received and it's not shown on the screen, so I apologize to the folks at home.

[Ruseau]: I certainly don't think that's good.

[Ruseau]: I'm just saying that from a raw data perspective, we have just chosen the agree and strongly agree

[Ruseau]: And those are what we called good forgiving scores.

[Ruseau]: We have a list of scores that we got.

[Ruseau]: Those scores are, there's no reason to have any scores if they're not going to actually be meaningful in relationship to each other, and they're not.

[Ruseau]: This says 90% for school engagement.

[Ruseau]: That could be good, that could be bad, depending on how the question was asked.

[Ruseau]: So we don't give grades out and be like, your A in this class might be a good thing, it might be a bad thing in this class.

[Ruseau]: And your D in this class might be a good thing or it might be a bad thing.

[Ruseau]: Like there's a point to the scores meaning something.

[Ruseau]: And so maybe if we just got rid of all of these percentages, that might make sense.

[Ruseau]: But by including them, it just is a very weird thing to have a report that seems to be

[Ruseau]: mixing and matching what's considered good.

[Ruseau]: Member Ruseau.

[Ruseau]: Here.

[Ruseau]: Mayor Longo.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: The bullying, excuse me, the rules and policy subcommittee has met five times over the course of the past winter and spring to update our bullying prevention and intervention policy, plan policy.

[Ruseau]: This proposed policy represents many hours of work in and out of meetings, drafting and redrafting language, researching how other school committees have written their policies, reading and rereading the law.

[Ruseau]: And I am proud of this work product before us tonight.

[Ruseau]: I see all policy as a statement of direction for our district leadership.

[Ruseau]: Policy is not written in stone.

[Ruseau]: This policy is not perfect.

[Ruseau]: No policy ever is.

[Ruseau]: Therefore, it is imperative that policy be regularly reviewed and based on actual outcomes, it should be changed so that the goal of the policy can be achieved.

[Ruseau]: I want to thank the members of the Rules and Policy Subcommittee.

[Ruseau]: Member McLaughlin, Member Graham.

[Ruseau]: I also especially want to thank Vice Chair Graham for her work to generate a new policy document rather than trying to transform our old policy document, which is how we tried to make that go.

[Ruseau]: But without her effort to sort of hit the blank page and start over, I think we would still be having meetings on this policy.

[Ruseau]: I also want to thank our administration and principals that took the time to share their experiences and insights, especially Principal Tucci of the Morgan Middle School and Assistant Superintendent Peter Cushing.

[Ruseau]: And finally, I'd like to thank the community members that were at every one of these meetings, especially Nicole Bramley, who single-handedly forced this policy into the crowded policy space of the school committee and helped us to understand from the caregiver perspective what was right and what was wrong with our policy.

[Ruseau]: I am deeply sorry that this attention to this policy required an incident

[Ruseau]: that we all know too well.

[Ruseau]: I am hopeful that this new policy will allow the Medford Public Schools to move forward with clarity on bullying prevention and intervention.

[Ruseau]: I am also hopeful that this drastically improved policy provides some resolution to Ms.

[Ruseau]: Branley and to those who have experienced bullying, and in many ways it harms our community and our students we serve.

[Ruseau]: And with that, I'd like to make a motion to amend line 261 to remove the

[Ruseau]: random period that is sitting in between a couple of words.

[Ruseau]: Mayor, you can answer those.

[Ruseau]: Thank you, Member Kreatz.

[Ruseau]: Target is used in the law in a bunch of places, but I would agree that Target is not in the definitions.

[Ruseau]: So, looking at the law right now, they don't

[Ruseau]: have a definition for it.

[Ruseau]: They have definitions for all kinds of things, then they use words that they don't have definitions for.

[Ruseau]: So I would agree that we would want to amend it to have some kind of definition to describe what target means.

[Ruseau]: I would say that I don't think I can do that on the fly right now.

[Ruseau]: So I mean, we want

[Ruseau]: I would certainly be happy to put a motion on for our first meeting in September to amend the policy with a definition if that's acceptable to Democrats.

[Ruseau]: understood, but it's also the law that this information cannot be handed down.

[Ruseau]: And that's a pretty old law at this point.

[Ruseau]: Whether a principal, I mean, this is in relation to bullying though.

[Ruseau]: And so I don't know what, at the early elementary level, how that is handled.

[Ruseau]: I assume it would be handled a little differently than it does for high school seniors, but

[Ruseau]: I don't envision that this restricts any of that in any other way other than making it clear that, in case there was any confusion, that you can't get a phone call saying, your child was bullied and here's the name of the kid that did it.

[Ruseau]: That's a clear violation of the law, not even regulation.

[Ruseau]: So whether or not, if your kid knows the name, which, I mean, it seems hard to imagine a kid doesn't know the name, how did there get to be a report?

[Ruseau]: you know, the kids, your child's gonna tell you their name.

[Ruseau]: And when you talk to the school, you might use the name and the school is going to respond as if that is, could be a name, it might not be the name.

[Ruseau]: They're not supposed to be responding that anything about that other student, at least their identity.

[Ruseau]: So I know that isn't always a great time when you're the parent of the target victim.

[Ruseau]: whatever word is appropriate, but that's definitely not new.

[Ruseau]: Yes, thank you.

[Ruseau]: The word power occurs is listed in the law seven times.

[Ruseau]: Power differential is listed.

[Ruseau]: I'm happy to share my screen if somebody wants to, doesn't believe it.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I'm on the mass legislature.gov website looking at the law myself.

[Ruseau]: Power differential is actually discussed.

[Ruseau]: And I don't know what to say other than that.

[Ruseau]: I think it's worth noting that power differential is always implied.

[Ruseau]: Otherwise, we're going to have no more sports teams.

[Ruseau]: Because stuff that happens on sports teams between people who are hanging out and doing things on sports teams, if we don't have power differential in this equation,

[Ruseau]: it's going to be considered bullying every day there.

[Ruseau]: At least how I think happens at a lot of sports teams.

[Ruseau]: Stuff that two people don't even think is bullying will be bullying because the policy requires that if an adult sees it, doesn't require that the students say they were bullied.

[Ruseau]: So I think that's a very, very important thing to recognize that we have

[Ruseau]: We have not required that the students say I was bullied.

[Ruseau]: We have said our staff is responsible for seeing something that we believe based on the definition is bullying and acting.

[Ruseau]: And that's the expectation.

[Ruseau]: Frankly, that's the expectation I think that's always existed for school staff.

[Ruseau]: I doubt anybody would disagree.

[Ruseau]: But because of that, I think that the definition does have to be pretty darn airtight because part of the reason we're here is that everybody had an opinion on whether it was bullying.

[Ruseau]: And then one person, the person who was dealing with it says it's not bullying.

[Ruseau]: And then five other people in the administration look at it and go,

[Ruseau]: How is that not bullying?

[Ruseau]: And I'm not suggesting that the people who are making these determinations that things are not bullying are doing anything wrong.

[Ruseau]: I'm saying they've had a pretty bad definition that is really hard to follow.

[Ruseau]: So that's just trying to give some feedback on what we've talked about in our five meetings.

[Ruseau]: But I certainly respect that the definition does look different.

[Ruseau]: But the word power and power differential is in the law multiple times.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Our policy number 46 does say that we would have two readings.

[Ruseau]: The first reading has to be approved for there to be a second reading.

[Ruseau]: Okay, thank you.

[Ruseau]: The second reading, my understanding is the second reading needs to be exactly what the first one was, what we voted it.

[Ruseau]: So second reading is not an opportunity to come in to continue to amend.

[Ruseau]: If we amend, then that's a new first reading.

[Ruseau]: It says that we're going to implement the recommendations from Mr. Welch and that it's budget neutral.

[Ruseau]: And I'm looking at the recommendations right now, including a 0.5 FTE Dean position,

[Ruseau]: the addition of an associate principal, the addition of four permanent substitute teachers.

[Ruseau]: So these would be, you know, full-time teachers.

[Ruseau]: Nobody can find a substitute, I get that.

[Ruseau]: But an actual teacher just in the teacher roles on the actual schedule as a teacher is a different, different thing to try to recruit for than a substitute.

[Ruseau]: So, all of those add up to an awful lot of money.

[Ruseau]: And I'm not sure how we can say that's budget neutral unless we're just not doing the recommendations from Mr. Welch for which we spent a good amount of money to get.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: And I also want to just share my concerns about.

[Ruseau]: We are in, we are purposefully increasing our fiscal cliff, one year before the cliff at the beginning of the pandemic.

[Ruseau]: It was a lot of like the federal government just seemed to have a blank check.

[Ruseau]: And so it was years away when we were going to be in full blown walking off the cliff.

[Ruseau]: We are well we're 12 months away from walking off the cliff, and we're going to make it a higher cliff.

[Ruseau]: I'm not saying we shouldn't add those other five, and that we shouldn't use our extra funds for that purpose.

[Ruseau]: I'm saying those should be in our operating budget to additional literacy coaches should be in our operating budget.

[Ruseau]: And frankly, an awful lot of other people that currently work for us that are in most of the districts operating budget employees.

[Ruseau]: that we're just pretending aren't going to somehow ever have to become part of our operating budget.

[Ruseau]: We're just closing our eyes and being like, well, next July is going to be terrible.

[Ruseau]: You know, you know something as bad as coming.

[Ruseau]: doing nothing about it is different than when something bad happens at the beginning of the pandemic.

[Ruseau]: Nobody was prepared.

[Ruseau]: And how well, maybe we could have some of there could have been some preparations but here we are 12 full months, and we're going to approve a budget, adding to the fiscal cliff, up to 33 and a half people who will either be laid off or some magical thing will somehow make 33 people

[Ruseau]: That's not $100,000.

[Ruseau]: That's not a million dollars.

[Ruseau]: I don't know what it is, but it's a lot of money.

[Ruseau]: And our normal annual increases are going to come anyways.

[Ruseau]: The teacher's contract is for 3%, I believe, in the next year.

[Ruseau]: We have other contracts that are going to increase.

[Ruseau]: And that is all in addition to the 33 and a half people.

[Ruseau]: That we are all going to sit around this table and say we don't want to get rid of because they're all important.

[Ruseau]: So, there are solutions.

[Ruseau]: The solutions all expire on December 31 and override before then would allow the mayor to start including that money in our budget next July 1.

[Ruseau]: When December 31 arrives, those people had better be looking for new employment.

[Ruseau]: And I don't I mean.

[Ruseau]: It's really insane.

[Ruseau]: So I just, I just find it fascinating that there's a massive free cash in City Hall.

[Ruseau]: And we're going to not even fund the meager improvements to the district we want to as a committee.

[Ruseau]: And we're just gonna like sail along at full speed right off the edge of that cliff, as if there are not, aside from the employees that are impacted.

[Ruseau]: There are no employees working in our school district who are not impacting our kids.

[Ruseau]: So, you know, all I care very much about the employees, we really get elected for the kids, and all of the needs being met by those employees are just going to stop being met because there's no creative way to take 33 and a half people's

[Ruseau]: full-time employment and just shove it onto other people and think that the work will get done.

[Ruseau]: We've sort of been doing that in Medford for a very long time.

[Ruseau]: So I'm deeply disappointed in 71 million, 71.8 million would not be satisfying.

[Ruseau]: It would be, in my mind, a minimum to not making the problem worse next year.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I'll get that in a minute.

[Ruseau]: I just, I was surprised to hear you use a number to describe the high school considering construction costs have gone up that again I'm sorry, I was surprised to hear you use the number 200 million for high school I don't think that there's a high school that could be built anywhere for 200 million anymore.

[Ruseau]: Great, thank you.

[Ruseau]: I thought you said a $200 million high school, and I was like, ooh, that would be something.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I appreciate your comments on the funding.

[Ruseau]: I do also want to point out that aside from the 33 and a half people, we have most of our paraprofessionals and revolving accounts, which is totally, perhaps not even allowed.

[Ruseau]: When I talked to the, the president of the Massachusetts school school.

[Ruseau]: No, the, the, the accounting, the school business operations at Maslow, I forget what their dental stands for.

[Ruseau]: operating budget employees out of revolving accounts was palpable.

[Ruseau]: And I'm a chair of the Shore Educational Collaborative as the Medford representative.

[Ruseau]: And it's a wonderful meeting because every month I get to sit down with school committee members who I have a relationship with at this point.

[Ruseau]: And I can ask them very pointed questions about things that we do and say, hey, do you do that?

[Ruseau]: And universally, nobody does what we do here, we have so many employees that are not on our operating budget.

[Ruseau]: And so when we look at, you know, the number on the DC website, well that that none of those employees are included in how much we spend on our schools.

[Ruseau]: So in reality we spend more on our schools than we are reporting that we do, which I suppose is

[Ruseau]: I guess that's a good thing, but it is a totally not transparent way of paying for people to work for us.

[Ruseau]: And it is also a highly risky thing when the pandemic hit and we shut down after school, we were all like, how are we gonna keep paying these people that are actually not in our operating budget because the money stopped flowing.

[Ruseau]: The residents have been giving the democratic option to decide to fund their schools should have already happened before March, because it's, it's, I mean the superintendent can't be, you know, as happened in 2020, you know, was given a weekend to cut $400,000 school committee had no input, because we couldn't have a meeting.

[Ruseau]: and then not tell her what that thing is.

[Ruseau]: So, just like with the number that we've been given.

[Ruseau]: And I guess three or four or 10 incidents that are equal power quarrels individually may be conflict, but is this implying that those can't be considered bullying?

[Ruseau]: I guess how they relate to bullying is sort of the part that still kind of confuses me.

[Ruseau]: Because I mean, in like in our real lives, there are people we might have conflict with and we might have conflict with them.

[Ruseau]: But if it's a professional setting, for instance, we may have conflict with them way more than three times regularly.

[Ruseau]: And

[Ruseau]: it's not bullying because that's not what's happening.

[Ruseau]: Just like, you know, we have conflict one time, two times, 15 times, and it'd be nice if we worked it out so we didn't have conflicts, but that might be just the normal way that relationship works versus bullying.

[Ruseau]: And I just don't understand how they intersect with bullying.

[Ruseau]: Senator Graham actually wants to talk about that more.

[Ruseau]: Um, but, and you do say investigator.

[Ruseau]: Right.

[Ruseau]: Thank you, that's really excellent point.

[Ruseau]: Anybody else on this one?

[Ruseau]: I don't know why I'm suddenly decided to try to drive a little bit, but it's clearly running.

[Ruseau]: And the staff are required to formally report the incidents

[Ruseau]: I don't know if we want to add some kind of wording here.

[Ruseau]: I don't know how to put it.

[Ruseau]: The best dial 911.

[Ruseau]: It doesn't matter if there's 20 other people there because they're all standing around thinking somebody else dialed 911

[Ruseau]: And, you know, I imagine scenarios perhaps in a lunchroom where there's multiple staff members and they all see an incident happen and somebody, they each think somebody else is going to do it.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, whether that's based on like, oh, there was an assistant principal there and I'm just a teacher or whatever, like, you know, whatever the stuff that goes on in someone's head as to like, oh, somebody else is obviously going to take care of this report.

[Ruseau]: If there are five adults in the room who work for us, there should be five of them making sure that the report is written.

[Ruseau]: And it doesn't matter where they are structurally in the organization, they are all responsible to make sure that one is done.

[Ruseau]: I mean, if they go up to Mr. Tucci and said, are you going to do a report?

[Ruseau]: And he says, yes.

[Ruseau]: I'm not saying we need five separate forms filled out, but short of an affirmation that somebody will be doing it and they know who it is, they are on the hook to make sure that it gets done, whether that's by them or not.

[Ruseau]: So I just really worry about that, similar to the car accident where everybody stands around and waits for the ambulance and never get called.

[Ruseau]: Not a dig at our staff, most people are really actually quite bad at it.

[Ruseau]: smacked my head into a wall about hats and hoods, and that anybody who works for Bedford Public Schools is confused about whether hats and hoods are allowed, is really very, very concerning about our ability to communicate to our staff what the policies are.

[Ruseau]: We, as the school committee, are barred from communicating with the staff about what our policies are.

[Ruseau]: That's against the law.

[Ruseau]: I can't send an email to the teaching staff and say, here's the policy that we passed.

[Ruseau]: That's not allowed.

[Ruseau]: And the message did not get out.

[Ruseau]: Well, we planned a lot for coming back into in-person, but I don't know that we planned for the student body to largely be unrecognizable.

[Ruseau]: And for teachers that have been teaching for many, many years to have like, it's like they showed up and it's a different planet or something, like all of the things going on that they had not experienced.

[Ruseau]: And maybe did not have training and supports and you know we didn't suddenly multiply the number of people in the assistant principal's office.

[Ruseau]: That like we did try our best to support them in coming back, but I feel like this would probably be like you know, in the history books will be one of the areas where we didn't.

[Ruseau]: So it's not that we didn't provide like.

[Ruseau]: adjustment Councilors and all those other people, but that's sort of for the students, but finding ways to support the teachers who just came into this situation.

[Ruseau]: A friend of mine is a, I think she's a second grade or third grade teacher.

[Ruseau]: And during the pandemic, we talked about like how there were not being, there were not a lot of special ed referrals coming in.

[Ruseau]: And she was, I was, I mean, I mentioned this on the floor, like I'm terrified that the referrals are down because there's no,

[Ruseau]: Well there's eyes on the students but eyes on a webcam is not the same thing.

[Ruseau]: And sure enough September arrived, and it was a madhouse of all these students who are completely undiagnosed or on untested for what they needed.

[Ruseau]: And how much of that could have ever really been supported is will be interesting thing some people I'm sure will study but, you know, we couldn't just magically create a second teacher to sit in every classroom or whatever that those people don't exist so I just think it's really important to recognize that the teaching staff wasn't prepared because they couldn't be prepared because we didn't know, none of us have been through this pandemic.

[Ruseau]: Even if we had pandemics every 25 years, we never would have had a pandemic on Zoom.

[Ruseau]: So it's like, no matter how more common pandemics become, this will be the first one where kids actually kept going sort of.

[Ruseau]: And I hope we can take a lot of these things away because the global authorities indicate we can expect more pandemics.

[Ruseau]: So maybe we can do a better job.

[Ruseau]: I'll stop talking about that.

[Ruseau]: I do just want to point out on page,

[Ruseau]: 41, there's a paragraph, I'm gonna read it, it's one paragraph.

[Ruseau]: I'm just really tired of this conversation and you probably don't know, because you haven't been to all of our meetings, but we have been having this conversation over and over again since returning from the pandemic.

[Ruseau]: Bathroom access and availability, and yes, I rolled my eyes, sorry, has been a significant issue in the overall supervision of students.

[Ruseau]: Bathrooms are scattered throughout the building and periodically are not functioning due to maintenance needs.

[Ruseau]: Some bathrooms are routinely closed deliberately to limit supervisory requirements for staff.

[Ruseau]: This is a relatively common practice in large comprehensive high schools.

[Ruseau]: but the number and location of open bathrooms at Medford High School changes on a daily and sometimes hourly basis, creating frustration and confusion for all involved.

[Ruseau]: These changes are usually a result of lack of monitoring coverage.

[Ruseau]: When monitors are not available, bathrooms are locked and students are sent to other bathrooms.

[Ruseau]: A couple of questions in there.

[Ruseau]: Students are sent to other bathrooms.

[Ruseau]: If there's nobody to cover it, they're not sent.

[Ruseau]: They're left to wander to find another bathroom.

[Ruseau]: Am I correct?

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Reasons make sense to me.

[Ruseau]: We have all had to go to the bathroom and not been able to find a bathroom though.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, the changes happening sometimes on a daily or hourly basis.

[Ruseau]: I mean, are we really getting signs up there on the fly in the moment that are always accurate to tell a student where to go?

[Ruseau]: Because, you know, my daughter doesn't go to her locker anymore.

[Ruseau]: She just violates the

[Ruseau]: policy, whatever it is, or at least in the handbook and carries all of her books with her in a backpack all day.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, that's partially related to scheduling and our lovely asbestos challenge we had in one of the halls that took out her locker area.

[Ruseau]: I still remember thinking four minutes was nuts.

[Ruseau]: Like, how can you get anywhere in four minutes?

[Ruseau]: And if you're like ninth grade is in this wing, maybe that makes sense.

[Ruseau]: 10th grade's in this wing.

[Ruseau]: But we have students traversing like the entire building in their three minutes.

[Ruseau]: Is there, I don't think 100% is an unreasonable expectation.

[Ruseau]: that every bathroom has a sign 100% of the time that correctly says where is an open bathroom, not 95% of the time, 100% of the time the sign is correct.

[Ruseau]: Like we have an awful lot of people working in that building.

[Ruseau]: And it's one thing that matters a lot to somebody who's looking for a bathroom.

[Ruseau]: And when we talk about student behaviors, well, one thing that's important is that we might wanna consider respecting our students.

[Ruseau]: And while I agree we can't have all the bathrooms open

[Ruseau]: plenty of very good reasons.

[Ruseau]: If the bathroom is closed and the sign says to go here and you go over there and that one's closed and there's no sign telling you where else to go, I would feel very disrespected as a student who is supposed to be in class learning.

[Ruseau]: I mean, we can ignore the fact that that means they're not getting an education while they're on the hunt for a bathroom.

[Ruseau]: It's obnoxious that I'm talking about bathrooms, but we have talked about it so many meetings that you have been lucky enough not to participate in.

[Ruseau]: And by the way, having to go pee isn't the only thing our students need to use bathrooms for, which, you know, we still don't have menstrual products in all of our bathrooms, but that's a different conversation.

[Ruseau]: If you would like to send me any comments or questions rather than raising your hand and just participating in the meeting, you can do that by sending me an email at pruseau at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Ruseau]: Please include your first and last name, your Medford Street address, if you are not a staff member, if you are a staff member, just say that, and your question or comment.

[Ruseau]: You could also log in on our Zoom meeting, which is https://mps02155-org.zoom.us, backslash J, backslash 974-999-49349.

[Ruseau]: pretty straightforward, remove the word new, it's not new.

[Ruseau]: Right now the policy is for any student, and it should say student or member of the school staff, which I think is great because we had wondered about whether we could just incorporate that.
