[Ruseau]: So if we don't pass a calendar at all, there is no first day of school.

[Ruseau]: We have somebody who wishes to speak online, I believe.

[Ruseau]: Yes, Charlene.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I still don't know what the three numbers on each.

[Ruseau]: Are you saying that every student that took the test got 219, 220, or 221?

[Ruseau]: So I understand ranges.

[Ruseau]: I just, I've never seen ranges displayed with three numbers or ranges like your 20 to 30 or your, there's never a middle number in a range as I've ever seen it.

[Ruseau]: So I don't,

[Ruseau]: this middle number, I mean, if you took all those middle numbers out, we would all be on exactly the same page that between 217 and 219 is 218.

[Ruseau]: I don't think I'm fine.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: So I understand the middle number now, but when I'm looking at this, I don't understand what a range is if you're not telling me what is the worst score a kid got and the best score a kid got, because as a school committee member, I don't really know

[Ruseau]: These ranges that are barely a point above or maybe two points above or below the median, they tell me nothing.

[Ruseau]: I mean, really, unless you're telling me that every kid in the district is performing that close to the median, which I will have to tell you, I really hope nobody tries to tell us that.

[Ruseau]: So I really do not still have a clue what the range part of this is trying to say.

[Ruseau]: Because I mean, as a school committee member, I want to know how are the kids in fourth grade

[Ruseau]: at the Brooks, the first one in that list, what's the range of scores that the fourth graders in science got in the winter?

[Ruseau]: outcomes for kids at different schools.

[Ruseau]: Yet, if you look at this, frankly, the Brooks is doing worse in science than the McGlynn, and the McGlynn and the Missituk are doing identically almost, and the Roberts looks a lot like the Brooks.

[Ruseau]: I just don't think that this is what this is saying.

[Ruseau]: The median, I think everybody can understand that.

[Ruseau]: Are these the error bars if this was a graph?

[Ruseau]: Like 200, this is the error bars if it was in a graphical form.

[Ruseau]: I've never seen these displayed as numbers.

[Ruseau]: I've only ever seen them actually displayed as a graph where you have the line and then you have a box where there's above and below and you can get a sense of how much you can trust the actual number.

[Ruseau]: So these other numbers outside of the median are telling you essentially how trustworthy that median is.

[Ruseau]: I know we're going to get these reports again in the future.

[Ruseau]: And I'm very happy about that I just I'm just asked that the the perspective of what the school committee might want to know.

[Ruseau]: Front and center to what the presentation looks like because

[Ruseau]: I love error bars, I really actually do, because I think they're really important for big data sets and really understanding trends, but I don't think that.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I'm not going to speak for all of us, but I have a hunch none of us ever want to see error bars around this data again.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I looked through this after we got it.

[Ruseau]: I read it top to bottom more than once because I was like, how can I be so dumb to have no idea what this means, which wasn't a great feeling since I think I'm pretty good at math.

[Ruseau]: I doubt Mr. Bloomberg will come and physically remove it send the check back.

[Ruseau]: Honestly, I mean, and I get it, we needed three and a half million because Medford refuses to pay for anything of ourselves.

[Ruseau]: So we had to look for other people to pay for it and now we're being screwed, okay, by a donation of three and a half million dollars.

[Ruseau]: It is beyond comprehension.

[Ruseau]: I think it's also beyond comprehension that it was a failure to know that this would happen before we even requested the funds from him.

[Ruseau]: I just cannot even believe that we're just going to roll with it that it's we took three and a half million for the library now we have to cut, whether it's 2.2 or 2.8 or 1.4, it doesn't matter what the number is we have to cut from the school, and the kids.

[Ruseau]: After two years of a pandemic where the second and third graders who are now fourth and fifth graders, a huge number of them really can't do math because I've sat with parents whose kids sat

[Ruseau]: The teachers did their best, but the kid was one of 20 tiles being taught math.

[Ruseau]: And every time their name came up, they thought they were being yelled at and they were just being talked to.

[Ruseau]: These kids, a lot of these kids didn't actually learn any math for two years.

[Ruseau]: And when are we gonna do it?

[Ruseau]: We're gonna cut the math interventionists.

[Ruseau]: We're not gonna do that.

[Ruseau]: We're gonna not worry about whether they're fed so they can come to school fully capable of engaging in the education they are getting.

[Ruseau]: It's just beyond comprehension that we would even hear that a $3.5 million donation means we have to cut school funding, send it back.

[Ruseau]: I'd like to see somebody come and try to physically remove the library.

[Ruseau]: He can have his name on the building, I don't care.

[Ruseau]: Is it legally not possible to send it back and why has that been investigated?

[Ruseau]: Mayor, that's a question for you.

[Ruseau]: Who said we can't send it back.

[Ruseau]: But if we delayed it till July 1st, and you could use the free cash and the revenue replacement, you wouldn't be cutting this budget.

[Ruseau]: And between July 1st and the next fiscal year, you could do an override, and then we wouldn't be in the hole.

[Ruseau]: But you won't do an override.

[Ruseau]: If I see this in my neighborhood house across the street, just sold for $1.1 million and I'm just like, what is going on?

[Ruseau]: But because of prop two and a half, we can tax that house more, but we gotta tax other houses less because we cannot increase our taxes more than two and a half percent.

[Ruseau]: So it doesn't matter if a whole quarter of the city sold their houses that were fully paid off and bought 30 years ago,

[Ruseau]: for a price that now looks amazing.

[Ruseau]: So if we sold all those houses for millions of dollars each, the taxes will go up exactly two and a half percent anyways.

[Ruseau]: We re-evaluate.

[Ruseau]: That's how come this year

[Ruseau]: Some people's taxes went down because those million dollar homes are getting taxed appropriately for the sale price.

[Ruseau]: But because we cannot collect more taxes than two and a half percent from the previous more than the last year.

[Ruseau]: We got to subtract that from somebody else's property taxes.

[Ruseau]: Is it absurd?

[Ruseau]: The whole system is absurd.

[Ruseau]: And honestly, I can't I get really.

[Ruseau]: Yeah.

[Ruseau]: worked up about how crazy the law is, but in the aggregate, the total amount of revenue collected from residential property tech property cannot increase more than two and a half.

[Ruseau]: And it doesn't matter if somebody walked in and started paying by every house on the street for $10 million, they'll pay a lot of taxes, somebody else will pay less.

[Ruseau]: to compensate for the increase in one place.

[Ruseau]: It's crazy and it's gross, frankly.

[Ruseau]: We did just adopt rules that require two readings of policies and while I think it's fine to wave the reading of policy updates.

[Ruseau]: I think an entirely new policy of this nature does need to be read.

[Ruseau]: Just this one time when we have it next time around I would hope we could perhaps wave the reading.

[Ruseau]: So thank you, everyone.

[Ruseau]: This is the dress code policy that we approved in the Rules and Policy Subcommittee on May 25th, and I will begin now.

[Ruseau]: It is the policy of the committee that the student and their parent, guardian, or caregiver hold the primary responsibility in determining the student's personal attire, hairstyle, jewelry, and personal items, e.g.

[Ruseau]: backpacks, book bags.

[Ruseau]: Schools are responsible for ensuring that student attire, hairstyle, jewelry, and personal items do not interfere with the health or safety of any student and do not contribute to a hostile or intimidating environment for any student.

[Ruseau]: The core values.

[Ruseau]: In relation to student dress, the district's core values are the following.

[Ruseau]: Students should be able to dress and style their hair for school in a manner that expresses their individuality without fear of unnecessary discipline or body shaming.

[Ruseau]: Students have the right to be treated equitably.

[Ruseau]: Dress code enforcement will not create disparities, reinforce or increase the marginalization of any group, nor will it be more strictly enforced against students because of racial identity, ethnicity, gender identity, gender expression, gender nonconformity, sexual orientation, culture or religious identity, household income, body size or type, or body maturity.

[Ruseau]: Students and staff are responsible for managing their personal distractions students should not face unnecessary barriers to school attendance, the universal dress code students must wear.

[Ruseau]: One, a top, which could be a shirt, blouse, sweater, sweatshirt, tank, tank top, et cetera, bottom, pants, shorts, skirt, dress, et cetera, and footwear.

[Ruseau]: This policy permits additional student attire requirements when necessary to ensure safety in certain academic settings, e.g.

[Ruseau]: physical education, science, or CTE courses, as well as recess.

[Ruseau]: Additionally, this policy allows for reasonable variation in required student attire for participation in activities such as swimming or gymnastics students may not wear clothing jewelry or personal items that contain.

[Ruseau]: that are pornographic, contain threats, or promote illegal or violent conduct, such as the unlawful use of weapons, drugs, alcohol, tobacco, or drug paraphernalia.

[Ruseau]: Demonstrate hate group association or affiliation and or use hate speech targeting groups based on race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, religious affiliation, or other protected groups.

[Ruseau]: intentionally show private parts, nipples, genitals, or buttocks, or undergarments, with the exception of bra straps.

[Ruseau]: Clothing must cover private parts in opaque, not able to be seen through material.

[Ruseau]: cover the items that cover the student's face to the extent that the student is not identifiable except clothing, headgear worn for religious or medical purposes, or demonstrate gang association or affiliation.

[Ruseau]: Attire worn in observance of a student's religion is not subject to this policy.

[Ruseau]: Clothing that displays profanity or other vulgarities can disrupt the learning environment.

[Ruseau]: School leaders reserve the right to address disruptions on a case-by-case basis.

[Ruseau]: Enforcement.

[Ruseau]: This is the last section member of stone principles are required to ensure that all staff are aware of and understand the core values and associated guidelines of this policy.

[Ruseau]: Staff will use reasonable efforts to avoid issuing dress code discipline to individuals in front of other students.

[Ruseau]: staff will use reasonable efforts to limit disciplinary, that disciplining or removing students from class as a consequence of wearing attire in violation of this policy, unless the attire creates a substantial disruption to the educational environment, poses a hazard to the health or safety of others, or factors into a student behavior rule violation, such as malicious harassment, or the prohibition on harassment, intimidation, and bullying.

[Ruseau]: Further, no student shall be referred to as a distraction due to their appearance or attire.

[Ruseau]: Typical consequences of a violation of this policy may include parent, guardian, caregiver conduct,

[Ruseau]: or reference conference and the directive to cover change or remove the non complying attire.

[Ruseau]: A student may be instructed to leave their classroom briefly to change clothes.

[Ruseau]: The principal or their designee will notify a student's parent, guardian or caregiver of the school's response to violations of student dress code policy.

[Ruseau]: And if I may just add a quick commentary, I really wanna thank aside from the members of the rules committee

[Ruseau]: and Policy Subcommittee, Member Graham and Member McLaughlin.

[Ruseau]: I also really want to thank the students of the Andrews Middle School, Mr. Scimante and Ms.

[Ruseau]: Whalen's class.

[Ruseau]: They worked on this project about the dress code around hoods.

[Ruseau]: That was their angle.

[Ruseau]: And of course, with this policy, hoods and hats will be allowed.

[Ruseau]: And I just can't thank them enough because they also provided feedback that was really useful in fine tuning this policy.

[Ruseau]: I also would recommend people listen to the podcast, No Caps, which was an NPR finalist.

[Ruseau]: And there was a new version of the Medford Bites podcast this two days ago, I believe, which is again on this policy.

[Ruseau]: Thank you to all of the students and the staff and the teachers that helped them.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Ruseau]: I would say it speaks for itself that you're the doll that's speaking.

[Ruseau]: So the fair share amendment is, is going to be on the ballot this fall and I urge everyone to vote for it because it will add a 4% additional tax for those with incomes, greater than a million dollars a year.

[Ruseau]: For most of us, it's hard to conceptualize what that even means, but that additional 4% will be used for schools and roads and.

[Ruseau]: We just had a very interesting evening about the lack of revenues.

[Ruseau]: So to alleviate some of that burden coming from the state would be nice.

[Ruseau]: So I do ask that everybody consider supporting this, not just tonight, but when you're talking to your friends and family and they're like, what is this fair share amendment?

[Ruseau]: It is just on income over a million dollars.

[Ruseau]: So if you have a million dollars in the bank, that's not income.

[Ruseau]: These are people who are getting a paycheck throughout the year that is more than a million dollars.

[Ruseau]: So it's 4% on that is not a lot of money, but it will add up to, I can't remember how many billions of dollars for education, so.

[Ruseau]: Motion to approve.

[Ruseau]: I don't think that one's ready yet.

[Ruseau]: The agenda for tonight is, as approved by the committee on October 18th, 2021, the Rules, Policy, and Equity Subcommittee will draft a student dress code JICA policy for the Medford Public Schools.

[Ruseau]: The policy recommendation will be returned to the school committee no later than February 28th, 2022.

[Ruseau]: The subcommittee will hold at least two meetings on this topic before sending a recommended policy to the school committee.

[Ruseau]: outreach to stakeholders will be made by the superintendent or her designee to ensure the subcommittee hears from students, teachers, and principals, the Mystic Valley NAACP, SAFE Medford, Interfaith Clergy Association of Medford, and any other advocacy group in Medford that may have an interest in this work.

[Ruseau]: will be notified prior to these meetings as we embark on our efforts to create a just equitable and inclusive student dress code.

[Ruseau]: The new suggested sentence is, clothing that displays profanity or other vulgarities can disrupt the learning environment.

[Ruseau]: Bathing suits, I mean, frankly, my son does go to school in a bathing suit.

[Ruseau]: It's his favorite kind of shorts.

[Ruseau]: And undergarments, most T-shirts and tank tops are undergarments for people of my age group, at least.

[Ruseau]: And I certainly understand the point.

[Ruseau]: You don't want somebody just showing up with a frilly pair of underwear

[Ruseau]: and, you know, or showing up in a bikini to school.

[Ruseau]: On the other hand, which I mean, would be incredibly uncomfortable at the high school.

[Ruseau]: It could be freezing or hot, you won't know.

[Ruseau]: But I'm just not sure how to include this

[Ruseau]: Yeah, I do want to acknowledge that you are absolutely right.

[Ruseau]: There are going to be students who are going to push the envelope very soon after this becomes policy, if it does pass.

[Ruseau]: So I don't want to ignore that.

[Ruseau]: I see Mr. Blanca.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I think your point, though, that we're really just talking about girls.

[Ruseau]: I don't want to see boy underwear either.

[Ruseau]: to be clear.

[Ruseau]: No, but about bathing suits.

[Ruseau]: Right.

[Ruseau]: If every boy tomorrow comes to school in swim trunks, there will be zero dress code, even with the current policy, not one boy will be receiving a dress code violation.

[Ruseau]: And if girls wear those same swim trunks, they also will not receive it.

[Ruseau]: So what we're really talking about here is how much of a

[Ruseau]: the female body, are we okay having visible in class?

[Ruseau]: That's what we're talking about.

[Ruseau]: And that, if I go back up to here, the core values, girls are not responsible for the reactions of the rest of their classmates and their teachers to their bodies.

[Ruseau]: That's our core value.

[Ruseau]: And so I,

[Ruseau]: I'm getting less and less comfortable around this idea.

[Ruseau]: I don't envision many girls having an interest in going to school in a two-piece bikini.

[Ruseau]: And if they do, it's for a reason such as attention and certainly not comfort.

[Ruseau]: But, you know,

[Ruseau]: Hey, I'd be okay with getting, saying no bathing suits, but I also want somebody at the door checking the backs of every one of the boys when they come in to see, is this a bathing suit or is this shorts?

[Ruseau]: And we're not gonna do that for many different reasons.

[Ruseau]: So.

[Ruseau]: I don't know who was next.

[Ruseau]: Suzanne, were you next?

[Ruseau]: Go ahead.

[Ruseau]: I do apologize for sharing it without actually even asking you, because I understood this as just being a jumping off a conversation point.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Mr. Began.

[Ruseau]: Yeah.

[Ruseau]: Yeah, thank you.

[Ruseau]: I certainly agree.

[Ruseau]: I also just, I'm just remembering an email I received from a student who pointed out that our current dress code policy seems to be perfectly fine with our cheerleaders wearing things that are not considered acceptable.

[Ruseau]: And I thought that was a very interesting thing to note that we, even with our policy that has been traditionally rather restrictive and conservative,

[Ruseau]: We not bad at an eyelash that in school sponsored during the school day events, we allowed the girls who are on the cheerleading team to wear clothes that they could not go to class in.

[Ruseau]: So I just think that's, it's really not possible to ignore the fact that this is a gendered conversation.

[Ruseau]: It is.

[Ruseau]: And

[Ruseau]: I lost my train of thought.

[Ruseau]: Jane, did you wanna speak?

[Ruseau]: And I think that either we're gonna follow policy or not.

[Ruseau]: And it can't just be when it's you don't like that sentence

[Ruseau]: And I certainly respected and apologize for suggesting that we should just write a policy that you'll just violate when you feel the need to.

[Ruseau]: And I am completely on board with the notion that our policies are not, you know, if we leave wiggle room, we put the wiggle room in the language.

[Ruseau]: And that's what we did for the discipline policy actually.

[Ruseau]: But I just wanna be clear that the policy we passed did not include wiggle room.

[Ruseau]: There are seven members.

[Ruseau]: If any one of us wants to write a motion to rescind that or it wouldn't be rescind at this point, but to make a motion to start charging kids for food, that would have to be on a regular agenda.

[Ruseau]: And until that happens, I don't really think we're having a conversation about whether it will be in the budget.

[Ruseau]: That's just my opinion based on the vote of seven members who in affirmative said we will no longer charge for food.

[Ruseau]: I just want to call out a couple of things.

[Ruseau]: First of all, I understand that there is literally no one, probably no one even in the entire Zoom here, who wants to charge kids for food.

[Ruseau]: Maybe I'm wrong.

[Ruseau]: You know, the drop in participation is absolutely will happen.

[Ruseau]: As we know this last year, participation was very robust over previous normal years.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, the effects of the pandemic are not done.

[Ruseau]: There are lots of people who are still hurting.

[Ruseau]: And as Member Graham mentioned, there are lots of people for which applying

[Ruseau]: represents in their minds a security risk to their families.

[Ruseau]: And it's not really an appropriate decision that anybody should have to make.

[Ruseau]: And I don't think anybody here is saying that's okay either.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: They were reaching out about how we can, on the school committee, continue to move us towards the Hunger-Free Medford Proclamation that was made.

[Ruseau]: And I had indicated that it is the current policy of the school committee that this will continue.

[Ruseau]: I didn't answer that as a school committee

[Ruseau]: as our opinion, but in fact, it was already voted so.

[Ruseau]: I don't actually remember if the mayor's office at the time was a participant in that, but, you know, it's three years old, two years old, the proclamation, three years old, I think.

[Ruseau]: you know, that's not a lot of time to be deciding we're just gonna give up on proclamations that we made a big deal about.

[Ruseau]: So not having this funded and free is moving us further away from making Medford hunger free.

[Ruseau]: I think that should be universally understood.

[Ruseau]: So if one direction is that there's nobody hungry in Medford, and one is that there are more people hungry in Medford, not including this in the budget will mean we have decided

[Ruseau]: not the administrators, this is not a moral conversation about your desires and intent, but we will have decided to make Medford more hungry.

[Ruseau]: It's just a simple fact, can't be denied.

[Ruseau]: So thank you.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: City is not allocating the resources and Mr. Murphy does beat it up a little bit over and over again about how we're just part of the city's portfolio, but as is the case in many school committees, we are not.

[Ruseau]: We have one responsibility, and it is not about how bad the roads are, how much money the rec department needs.

[Ruseau]: have any other departments need money.

[Ruseau]: We don't have any way to get information about their needs.

[Ruseau]: So I think that focusing on what the schools need to the complete exclusion of the other stuff, since we cannot ask or know anything about it is just responsible.

[Ruseau]: I drive them too.

[Ruseau]: but we and the school committee don't have anything to do with the roads.

[Ruseau]: Member McLaughlin.

[Ruseau]: Yes.

[Ruseau]: Member Mustone.

[Ruseau]: Member Ruseau, yes.

[Ruseau]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn.

[Ruseau]: Member Ruseau?

[Ruseau]: If the audience can't be heard, I'm not sure we can continue this.

[Ruseau]: Those are just the increases.

[Ruseau]: So when it says $200,000 for gas, it is not that we're spending $200,000 on gas, we're spending $200,000 more than we did this year.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I just wanted to provide a little more sort of to answer the question about our historical increases year over year.

[Ruseau]: From 2007 to 2012, we increased by 1.9% total over the course of those five years.

[Ruseau]: But, you know, we added $869,000 over the course of five years.

[Ruseau]: So how on earth we functioned and ran a district during that time is sort of a fascinating thing.

[Ruseau]: I'm sure somebody could write a book on.

[Ruseau]: But, you know, we have plenty of years for which we not only didn't increase, but we even cut.

[Ruseau]: 2010, we cut.

[Ruseau]: 2011, we

[Ruseau]: added enough to buy a copier.

[Ruseau]: So I, you know, I'm happy that since 2013, it looks like we have been doing the percentage increases that are still probably too low in my book, but at least they're not like, what is going on?

[Ruseau]: These zero percents and these cuts year over year, I don't even know how we functioned and I'm sure there's plenty of people here who were here then and could tell me, but,

[Ruseau]: It must've been interesting.

[Ruseau]: So I just did have that data and I wanted to provide some context.

[Ruseau]: but only half of us have to abide by them.

[Ruseau]: So when we are asked questions that we cannot answer, because that would be a Department of Labor violation, that's fine.

[Ruseau]: But when the other side wants to violate those same rules, we don't say boo, we don't contact the Department of Labor over it.

[Ruseau]: Instead, you get to like, say whatever you want, and we can't respond.

[Ruseau]: Because if we respond, that's against the law.

[Ruseau]: So I want the rules that were agreed to for this bargaining

[Ruseau]: to be publicly available so that when they are violated by anyone, including us, everybody knows what's really going on.

[Ruseau]: Because this is just, this is the same thing from the last time we had bargaining where I left the bargaining table because members of the bargaining table, not on the school committee, went on Facebook and talked about what was going on in the bargaining room, which is a violation of trust.

[Ruseau]: And I think trust is critical to a good bargaining.

[Ruseau]: So I want, there's a motion and a second.

[Ruseau]: I don't want a conversation.

[Ruseau]: There's a motion and a second.

[Ruseau]: Mayor, if I may?

[Ruseau]: I guess, I don't really know what the point of rules are if they are not followed by one half of the people at the table.

[Ruseau]: And I see somebody shaking her head who went to Facebook after the last collective bargaining agreement and session that I was in and divulged everything that was being discussed.

[Ruseau]: It's, you know, the community, we're the seven people that get beat up and you can say anything you want,

[Ruseau]: I'm not saying everybody's lying, but you also can say anything you want.

[Ruseau]: And we can't even respond to the emails.

[Ruseau]: We can say, thank you for your email.

[Ruseau]: We like our teachers too.

[Ruseau]: And we think they should get a big raise.

[Ruseau]: That's how I respond.

[Ruseau]: But you could say, we offered you zero, zero, zero.

[Ruseau]: And I couldn't respond and say, you asked for 20%, 20%, 20%.

[Ruseau]: That would be against the law for me to do that.

[Ruseau]: So I just don't know what the point of bargaining partners are that aren't actually partners.

[Ruseau]: I'll withdraw this because I recognize that the motion as I put it was for all the bargaining agreement, bargaining partners, but I just would be nice if the other side of the table respected the process that they agreed upon, because we respect that process by staying silent and allowing the bargaining to happen according to the law.

[Ruseau]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Ruseau]: I'd like to make a motion to suspend rule number 46, requiring two readings of this, since there is in fact no content change.

[Ruseau]: It is just a correction to the numbering.

[Ruseau]: Mayor.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: In consultation with the superintendent's office, there's still some clarity we need to

[Ruseau]: get to on our agenda creation, which, you know, we did make such a huge change that doesn't surprise me.

[Ruseau]: The way that I had understood report requests is that we would make the report requests, they would be new business, and then they would stay on the agenda under reports requested until satisfied.

[Ruseau]: So I

[Ruseau]: believe that was the intent of the committee.

[Ruseau]: And that's why it's on here.

[Ruseau]: Excellent.

[Ruseau]: the dress code policy, which we discussed.

[Ruseau]: We had some community feedback and input in the last meeting.

[Ruseau]: We discussed, I was trying to have us not steer into the specific policy, but it was hard not to go there.

[Ruseau]: And so I have drafted, and when I say I've drafted, I've stolen for the most part, as a lot of policies are.

[Ruseau]: No sense to reinvent the wheel.

[Ruseau]: A dress code policy that I thought we could use as a,

[Ruseau]: As a place to begin, frankly, let me share that.

[Ruseau]: I have sent it to member Graham, member McLaughlin, Dr. Edouard-Vincent, and the assistant superintendent for elementary as well as secondary, but they received it in a blind CC, so we could not have dialogue, but I wanted to give them a chance to read it beforehand.

[Ruseau]: Okay, so as I mentioned, a lot of this has been much, most of it, frankly, has been taken from the Seattle dress code policy, which I personally really like because it is, aside from being short, it leaves relatively little up to interpretation, which is sort of the biggest challenge around dress codes and implementation.

[Ruseau]: So I'm going to,

[Ruseau]: I am going to read it.

[Ruseau]: It's two pages with lots of spacing.

[Ruseau]: So the dress code is the policy of the committee that the student and their parent, guardian, caregiver hold the primary responsibility in determining the student's personal attire, hairstyle, jewelry, and personal items, i.e., or e.g., backpacks, book bags,

[Ruseau]: Schools are responsible for ensuring that student attire, hairstyle, jewelry, and personal items do not interfere with the health or safety of any student and do not contribute to a hostile or intimidating environment for any student.

[Ruseau]: Core values in relation to student dress, this district's core values are as follows.

[Ruseau]: By the way, obviously, I'm asserting these are our core values having actually not been told that we all agree these are our core values.

[Ruseau]: Students should be able to dress and style their hair for school in a manner that expresses their individuality without fear of unnecessary discipline or body shaming.

[Ruseau]: Students have the right to be treated equitably

[Ruseau]: Dress code enforcement will not create disparities, reinforce or increase marginalization of any group, nor will it be more strictly enforced against students because of racial identity, ethnicity, gender identity, gender expression, gender nonconformity, sexual orientation, cultural or religious identity, household income, body size, type, or body maturity.

[Ruseau]: Students and staff are responsible for managing their personal distractions, and students should not face unnecessary barriers to school attendance.

[Ruseau]: So those are the core values.

[Ruseau]: The dress code is students must wear a top, which is a shirt, blouse, sweater, sweatshirt, tank, et cetera, bottom, pants, shorts, shirt, dress, et cetera, and footwear.

[Ruseau]: This policy permits additional student attire requirements when necessary to ensure safety in certain academic settings, such as physical activity,

[Ruseau]: gym, science, or CPE courses.

[Ruseau]: There are specific requirements for many of those areas.

[Ruseau]: Additionally, this policy allows for reasonable variation in required student attire for participation in activities such as swimming or gymnastics.

[Ruseau]: Students may not wear clothing, jewelry, or personal items that are pornographic,

[Ruseau]: contain threats or that promote illegal or violent conduct such as the unlawful use of weapons, drugs, alcohol, tobacco, or drug paraphernalia, demonstrate hate group affiliation, association or affiliation, and or use hate speech targeting groups based on race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity,

[Ruseau]: religious affiliation, or other protected groups.

[Ruseau]: Intentionally show private parts, nipples, genitals, or buttocks.

[Ruseau]: Clothing must cover private parts and opaque, not able to be seen through materials.

[Ruseau]: Cover the student's face to the extent that the student is not identifiable, except clothing or headgear worn for religious or medical purposes, or demonstrate gang affiliation or association.

[Ruseau]: Attire worn in observance of a student's religion is not subject to this policy.

[Ruseau]: Enforcement.

[Ruseau]: This is probably where we'll probably want to have some real discussion around this because I frankly don't feel strongly about its principles or assistant superintendents, assistant

[Ruseau]: But principles are required to ensure that all staff are aware of and understand the guidelines of this policy.

[Ruseau]: Staff will use reasonable efforts to avoid dress coding students in front of other students.

[Ruseau]: Students shall not be disciplined or removed from class as a consequence for wearing attire in violation of this policy, unless the attire creates a substantial disruption to the educational environment, poses a hazard to the health or safety of others, or factors into a student behavior rule violation, such as malicious harassment or the prohibition on harassment, intimidation, and bullying.

[Ruseau]: No student shall be referred to as a distraction due to their appearance or attire.

[Ruseau]: Typical consequences for a violation of this policy include parent, guardian, caregiver contact or conference and the directive to cover, change or remove the non-compliant attire.

[Ruseau]: A student may be instructed to leave their classroom briefly to change clothes.

[Ruseau]: The principal or their designee

[Ruseau]: should notify a student's parent, guardian, caregiver of the school's response to violations of the student dress policy.

[Ruseau]: Actually, dress code policy.

[Ruseau]: So that's draft one.

[Ruseau]: I imagine there are people who have feedback.

[Ruseau]: So I'll open the floor for thoughts, comments.

[Ruseau]: I'll just jump in on what my thoughts are on that particular thing.

[Ruseau]: What I understand that to mean is students can be removed from class under certain circumstances, but if I come to school and

[Ruseau]: It's really hard to come up with examples because frankly the stress code is very permissive.

[Ruseau]: But if I come to school and I'm violating the dress code somehow, and I am not creating a substantial disruption to the environment or creating obviously the hazard and health and safety stuff, I'm still violating it, but like the class can go on.

[Ruseau]: You know, a teacher stopping the class to say,

[Ruseau]: you know, your pants are too low and I can see your buttocks.

[Ruseau]: Well, the student is sitting in their chair in the back row.

[Ruseau]: There's an example where it's like, that can wait till the class is over rather than stopping the class and making the student a spectacle.

[Ruseau]: Or frankly, if you notice it when the student's coming in, then, you know, before class starts.

[Ruseau]: But because it's such a permissive policy, it is kind of hard to think about like,

[Ruseau]: How do you even get to the point where you're in a classroom.

[Ruseau]: I know that it was having a process just getting going and then having it derailed

[Ruseau]: can make it a lot harder to get back to where you were.

[Ruseau]: I do just, I want to mention that school committees are explicitly forbidden from selecting curriculum.

[Ruseau]: So I would just ask that we actually not take a vote to approve or not.

[Ruseau]: Obviously it should be in the budget, but I think that there's a precedent issue here.

[Ruseau]: If we approve this, the next curriculum somebody else comes forward with, if we disagree with it,

[Ruseau]: it would be awkward for us to either not be asked to approve it or to not approve it when in fact we don't have authority in that regard.

[Ruseau]: So I would just ask that we not take any vote.

[Ruseau]: I'm very supportive of this, but that's not our authority.

[Ruseau]: So that's just my opinion.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: There was a lot there.

[Ruseau]: I noticed this.

[Ruseau]: There's a focus on the summer for the summer stuff for the rising 10th graders.

[Ruseau]: Can you just tell me, you know,

[Ruseau]: Desi apparently feels like these rising 11th and 12th graders don't need anything.

[Ruseau]: I'm assuming we have a good number of rising, we don't have the MCAS results yet.

[Ruseau]: So I'm gonna go out on a limb and bet we have a number of rising 11th and 12th graders who still have not passed their MCAS competencies.

[Ruseau]: Pardon me, I hope that was not really loud.

[Ruseau]: Since we're not offering any camps for them, what are we doing for those kids?

[Ruseau]: Can I just follow up real quick?

[Ruseau]: So the current 10th graders are the first students, the 11th and 12th graders are excluded from having to have passed their competencies to get a diploma, correct?

[Ruseau]: Yes.

[Ruseau]: I realized that we won't really know until we get MCAS results this fall or this summer, whether we're talking about, I mean, I don't know what a normal year, how many 10th graders are not going to get a diploma if we don't do something, if it's two or three, but if it's, and I suppose the state is very much waiting, I'm sure Jesse is already feverishly looking at results, and either there's a huge wave of students who they're gonna have to either not give a diploma to after they,

[Ruseau]: get through 12 years of school, or they're going to have to throw out the competency requirement.

[Ruseau]: And I'm sure that will be a front page story for several days.

[Ruseau]: But I always want to go on the assumption that DESE won't change their mind.

[Ruseau]: And so if they're not going to change their mind, I just want to make sure we are

[Ruseau]: maybe it's a bit cart before the horse since we don't have results, but I'm just very worried about 10th graders that are not going to get a diploma and are we throwing enough resources at them to get them there?

[Ruseau]: So I may be off topic slightly, sorry.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I just feel like if we had one user fee, and if a student wanted to participate in band or hockey or, well, frankly, anything else, they'd pay the one fee for the year, and they could participate in all of the things.

[Ruseau]: The only way I can see how that could limit would be as if participation rates went through the roof and we couldn't figure out how to have enough coaches and transportation.

[Ruseau]: If the band was tripled in size overnight, I'm sure that the band folks would be more than thrilled, but we have to acknowledge that would also cost an awful lot more money.

[Ruseau]: So I'm not sure what you meant by limiting when you referenced the idea of getting rid of user fees or universal user fees.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I certainly, when I was talking about a universal fee was,

[Ruseau]: one fee, like you pay once, you know, when you go to college, as many of us remember, or have seen, if we have kids that we're enrolling and you compare tuition, you'll get a very, very, you'll be in for a shock when you discover that most of what you're paying is called fees.

[Ruseau]: And that's how they sort of hidden that stuff.

[Ruseau]: But, you know, in my mind, like if students want to participate in anything and they pay

[Ruseau]: whatever it is, whether it's $100 for the year, then they can participate in anything.

[Ruseau]: And I just feel like that that would encourage kids to try out for things that they may not truly

[Ruseau]: have an aptitude for already.

[Ruseau]: If my son comes home and says, I wanna do hockey and he's never skated and he's never played hockey.

[Ruseau]: And then you tell me it's $200, I'm probably gonna be a little bit like, well, we need to really think this through and not be the most encouraging parent on earth, especially if $200 is a lot of money for me.

[Ruseau]: So lowering the barriers, but also keeping the students on free and reduced lunch, not paying anything.

[Ruseau]: You know, I think that that could open the door to a heck of a lot more participation by students, but I'll stop talking.

[Ruseau]: Yes, it is complicated.

[Ruseau]: I actually, this is just Robert's rules here.

[Ruseau]: And I thought it was really important to have the two of them back to back and have them in here so that if a member is in a meeting and needs to,

[Ruseau]: do one of these two things, or they don't have to go, you know, you can go to the Roberts Rules website, you will not find this, they want you to buy their book.

[Ruseau]: So you'll have to find your book and you'll have to figure out the right way to do it.

[Ruseau]: So this is, there is nothing in this that is not exactly what Roberts Rules requires.

[Ruseau]: And so I do want that to be clear that I've not changed the rules.

[Ruseau]: I'm just, this is a particular rule that I'm elevating into the document because

[Ruseau]: I know as a member, I think this is a complicated thing to keep those two things under, to keep them clear.

[Ruseau]: And it felt like other members might also find that helpful.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Yes, the word hyperlink was used, hyperlinks mean going to a webpage, but these are not available on the web.

[Ruseau]: So can we just, would you change the language of that to be just a reference?

[Ruseau]: No, Robert's rules.

[Ruseau]: No, the rules, our rules.

[Ruseau]: And even within their own FAQ, they will include a reference, you know, the RONR page 146 and edition 29 or 12 or whatever it is.

[Ruseau]: You cannot refer to the individual rules of Robert Rules of Order on the web because they are proprietary copyrighted or whatever the right language is.

[Ruseau]: So it is not possible to add a reference to what the language in Robert Rules of Order is.

[Ruseau]: Mayor Longo?

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: So, the part about adding to the agenda I actually, I don't know what the right process should be the city council in the last couple of years has in fact asked things that they wanted the school committee to respond to, and we got an email from somebody I think in the mayor's office.

[Ruseau]: To all of us as individuals, we as individuals have no authority to respond to the for the school committee, so we have no process right now at the school at the city council wants to ask the school committee a question.

[Ruseau]: There's no way for that to happen.

[Ruseau]: And any of us showing up at the city council to answer as the representative of the school committee in our last meeting, we just made that clear.

[Ruseau]: That is not acceptable either.

[Ruseau]: So I don't know what the process is now, but ignoring the city council, which I think we should respect them and as another body in our city, they deserve our respect, but we have no process for how to respond to them.

[Ruseau]: So that's all I'm trying to lay out here is some process.

[Ruseau]: It can be any process.

[Ruseau]: It doesn't have to be using our format.

[Ruseau]: It can be somebody, the president of the council, the city clerk.

[Ruseau]: I don't care who sends an email to the superintendent and asks that it be added to the agenda.

[Ruseau]: I don't have any preferences at all in that.

[Ruseau]: This was just my first thought is that we already have a process.

[Ruseau]: So it's not that complicated.

[Ruseau]: So why not use it?

[Ruseau]: But it doesn't have to be that.

[Ruseau]: As for the part about the superintendent,

[Ruseau]: being called to the city council.

[Ruseau]: We have an org chart on page, I think, two or three of our budget every single year, going back to at least 1997, that says the organization of our government, the superintendent has no line in any way, shape or form with the city council.

[Ruseau]: When the city council beckons a superintendent, she should not jump.

[Ruseau]: there is absolutely no relationship between the superintendent and the city council.

[Ruseau]: And I think it's not fair to the superintendent.

[Ruseau]: I mean, what if we had a city council that expected the superintendent at every meeting to answer questions?

[Ruseau]: So now Monday nights are school committee and Tuesday nights are city council meetings.

[Ruseau]: We need to make it crystal clear that if the city council wants to talk to the superintendent, we have to give permission for that to happen because that's actually the facts.

[Ruseau]: That is a fact.

[Ruseau]: It's not really a discussion point, it's a fact.

[Ruseau]: And I think it might be collegial and nice if the superintendent just shows up whenever they ask, but there's only so many hours in the day the superintendent works for this body.

[Ruseau]: And I think that expecting the superintendent to report to two public bodies is just highly inappropriate.

[Ruseau]: So that's why I wrote this rule.

[Ruseau]: That's all I can say so far.

[Ruseau]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Ruseau]: Superintendent said something really important that I want to highlight.

[Ruseau]: The individual Councilors emailing the superintendent to ask a question is absolutely not what this is about.

[Ruseau]: Just like with school committee members, individual Councilors have no authority.

[Ruseau]: And if they email the superintendent and ask a question and the superintendent responds, they're a member of the public asking a question and that's fine.

[Ruseau]: I'm talking about when there are votes happening and they are, you know, if they,

[Ruseau]: As member Graham mentioned, we have big expensive things coming up in conversations around our schools.

[Ruseau]: And it is both, I expect, and it would be surprised if the council does not have questions, big questions, report size questions, go do some analysis questions.

[Ruseau]: I mean, these are big expensive things that they have to consider if

[Ruseau]: if there's going to be a debt exclusion or something like that.

[Ruseau]: So I expect them to be doing this and for them to have, you know, a direct line to the superintendent when it is, I mean, and I know that the superintendent said, you know, if they ask for something big, then obviously she'll not necessarily push back, but she'll seek the guidance of the committee on an agenda.

[Ruseau]: But I think that having a process ahead of time is also good because

[Ruseau]: then it doesn't look like we have gotten sick of all these requests from the council and we're pushing back.

[Ruseau]: That's not the goal of this at all.

[Ruseau]: I would agree that in my, this is my fifth year now, it's not been a problem, but I expect it will become not a problem, but something that will happen as we deal with ARPA and perhaps a new high school.

[Ruseau]: So this is definitely just about when the body takes the time to take a vote,

[Ruseau]: what happens to that communication?

[Ruseau]: Because I think there have been at least two instances where the body took a vote asking for something, I think from the school committee and nobody knew what to do with it.

[Ruseau]: I mean, how do we respond?

[Ruseau]: And I don't even think we even have a rule in there, maybe we do, about how do we respond?

[Ruseau]: What do we do with a response to the city council if we have a response?

[Ruseau]: I don't know.

[Ruseau]: We vote and hope they watch the meeting on Monday night

[Ruseau]: That's not a real line of communication, but that's a different rule probably.

[Ruseau]: So that's all I have to say on this.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Member Cress just made a point that I think is really important.

[Ruseau]: Nobody here knew what the process was, but apparently the mayor and the superintendent.

[Ruseau]: The point of the rules document is that we are all equal on this board.

[Ruseau]: None of us knew what the process was.

[Ruseau]: So I think it's fascinating that we're putting all kinds of trust in the process and nobody knew what it was, but the mayor.

[Ruseau]: That seems kind of hard to wrap my head around.

[Ruseau]: I also don't think we can pass a rule that tells the city council president what she will do.

[Ruseau]: So I don't think we can specify that the city council president will do something.

[Ruseau]: So I think that part of that motion doesn't make sense to me because we don't have the authority to tell the city council president what to do.

[Ruseau]: I suppose you could say that the city clerk

[Ruseau]: We also can't tell the city clerk what to do.

[Ruseau]: However, the city clerk is an employee and is the person who manages motions that are passed by the council.

[Ruseau]: So that person certainly seems the obvious natural one.

[Ruseau]: I guess we could also have the rule say that a member of administration will watch all city council meetings and respond appropriately if they come up, but that would be horrible and burdensome.

[Ruseau]: We did have a motion earlier

[Ruseau]: to change the language to be strength-based, to remove the not authorized and make it authorized and change the without a majority vote to just with a majority vote.

[Ruseau]: I would second that before we start going into the three or four amendments and changes we've gotten into.

[Ruseau]: So I don't know if there's interest in a roll call on that.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I'm very excited by this, this integrated approach.

[Ruseau]: I know that as a student myself, when I remember math, I was very strong in math, but terrible in geometry.

[Ruseau]: And it really derailed my entire mathematics education because there was like a whole year bump.

[Ruseau]: And so this is very exciting.

[Ruseau]: I have a number of questions, I'll just ask two and then we can go around Robin if other people have questions and come back to me.

[Ruseau]: But so how will this be reported on report cards in the student record?

[Ruseau]: Because I mean, I have to admit, I don't remember how colleges consume the student's record, but a math course simply saying course one probably isn't

[Ruseau]: much to go on and much to compare when they're looking at students to admit that'd be my first question.

[Ruseau]: So, that answers my second question but my third question is, are there any.

[Ruseau]: Well, it feels like there are going to be some risks associated with students that are coming in midstream or leaving midstream in their academic career and have you already.

[Ruseau]: I realized we're doing a pilot this year with grade nine so you don't have to have answers yet, but that in particular concerns me, I suppose, since we're going to be keeping both for now.

[Ruseau]: it's probably less of a concern, but like if Waltham has abandoned the traditional approach completely, and a student comes in and they have just completed algebra one in Medford, and they're going there and they want to take geometry, but they just have course two, which isn't geometry.

[Ruseau]: This seems like this could be a risk for students transitioning in and out of our district.

[Ruseau]: So have you been thinking about that or?

[Ruseau]: Great, thank you.

[Ruseau]: I mean, certainly, you know, when I think about a student in this situation, I mean, they may not be on an IEP, or they may be, and each student, especially if they were not coming from a district in Massachusetts, for instance, I suppose this is a longstanding problem for students coming from other countries or just from other states, but I would just want to make sure we've

[Ruseau]: prepared so that the students who may in fact end up being future engineers and mathematicians don't land here and get completely derailed by that because it seems like too much to ask that the math teacher.

[Ruseau]: who is teaching a curriculum to the class of students is then also attempting to teach a totally different curriculum, frankly, to one or two students in their class.

[Ruseau]: So I know that you've said you've been thinking about it.

[Ruseau]: It's just something that worries me because we do have relatively high turnover of students, although I don't actually know where is that in the younger grades or in the older grades.

[Ruseau]: And so,

[Ruseau]: For students that are experiencing those transitions, they're often experiencing them, especially mid year, not in the best of circumstances.

[Ruseau]: So we just want to make sure we can find a way to take care of them and help them along their academic careers.

[Ruseau]: I'll just ask my last question since I only have one more.

[Ruseau]: Does this create any problems or has the MCAS already been aligned to this?

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: So as the members may know, the Medford City Council is drafting a new ordinance called the CCOPS or C-C-O-P-S.

[Ruseau]: And that is in layman terms, how the police camera, the body worn cameras, how that data will be managed and the oversight and

[Ruseau]: maintenance of that data and all that stuff they're drafting an ordinance on that.

[Ruseau]: And one thing I consider it concerns about was that while the city council obviously is drafting an ordinance that covers all of Medford, they are not necessarily particularly well versed in education law and the federal education privacy.

[Ruseau]: I probably can't remember all the letters, what they mean.

[Ruseau]: And so my request is that the committee gives one of us, and I obviously volunteer, the authority to show up to these meetings and speak, not just as a member of the public, but as a member of the school committee, which we shouldn't be doing unless we all agree that that's appropriate, just to make sure that

[Ruseau]: they're not missing this issue.

[Ruseau]: One thing that I know if you agree to this and you select me, I will insist that they have passed the ordinance through educational law specialists, not just the regular legal services that they use, but that they have passed it through that because an ordinance on how body-worn cameras can be used once you're on school property,

[Ruseau]: you know, the City Council can't pass an ordinance that exceeds federal or state law.

[Ruseau]: That's not one of their options.

[Ruseau]: None of us can do that.

[Ruseau]: So I just think it's really important that before this ordinance is fully drafted and becomes, you know, approved, that we've had some kind of, had our fingers in the pie, because there's really nothing worse than an ordinance that is completely done and approved

[Ruseau]: And then turns out it's violating the law.

[Ruseau]: Nobody wants that.

[Ruseau]: So that's what this is about.

[Ruseau]: And I believe the next meeting is on March 16th, which I believe is a Wednesday.

[Ruseau]: And if the members approve this, I do volunteer.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Well, I mean, I'm not a lawyer so I can't actually make that determination.

[Ruseau]: But members, we as a body can certainly appoint a member to act on our behalf.

[Ruseau]: but that is not to say that I don't have the voting rights on the city council.

[Ruseau]: So when I say acting on our behalf, it's making sure that the conversation is including, okay, when the police show up and they're on school property, that is not the same law as when they're not on school property.

[Ruseau]: And has the ordinance considered it?

[Ruseau]: Did they actually pull in?

[Ruseau]: Because all their ordinances go through a legal review.

[Ruseau]: They don't just like,

[Ruseau]: like a lot of our policies, we don't just jot them down and pass them and call it a day.

[Ruseau]: They go through a legal department to make sure that they're meeting whatever laws they need to meet.

[Ruseau]: And it's entirely plausible that that would happen here.

[Ruseau]: But it seems also possible that it could be a blind spot.

[Ruseau]: that this is a relatively new thing that the police reform, I forget what it's called, the Reform Act of last year around police accountability, that's all from last year, maybe the year before.

[Ruseau]: So I just think it's important that we get out ahead of it because if we don't, and the ordinance allows, for instance, the police to come on campus with their recording going on,

[Ruseau]: And then that turns out to be a violation of FERPA, which I don't know that it would be.

[Ruseau]: I mean, again, my point is to make sure that we are, before this is passed, that we are actually making sure that the specialized case of student privacy is really being included in the ordinance when it's drafted.

[Ruseau]: It's not to say that I, as I'm not a lawyer, and I could not comment on to whether the language is legal or not,

[Ruseau]: But, and since I wouldn't be voting, all I'm asking is that you give one of us and it doesn't have to be me permission to go and speak for us and speaking for us since we're not voting is not.

[Ruseau]: I would obviously be very happy to come back and report back on what's going on in that group.

[Ruseau]: I think that makes a lot of sense that the subcommittee, that I come back and report to the full committee, you know, what I'm seeing and hearing.

[Ruseau]: And if I have any other, if I have any concerns, be happy to do that.

[Ruseau]: But yeah, so I do think it's really important that, I mean, I could just go as a member of the public,

[Ruseau]: we're not just members of the public.

[Ruseau]: And if I go there and I stand there and I'm talking about school committee policy and educational law, that's not really okay.

[Ruseau]: That's not appropriate for us to be doing that.

[Ruseau]: It looks like, whether or not it is, it will look like I'm speaking for the school committee.

[Ruseau]: And so that's why I think it's important that somebody here goes and speaks for the school committee.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I certainly understand the reservation.

[Ruseau]: I think that that just sounds like going as a member of the public.

[Ruseau]: And just as if the mayor shows up to a public meeting and speaks, nobody in the community thinks he's just Breanna Lungo-Koehn, nobody.

[Ruseau]: So you can't speak as a member of the public, even though technically you can.

[Ruseau]: because you are the mayor and I can't speak as a member of the public because I'm an elected official.

[Ruseau]: So I think, if I show up to the meeting as a member of the public and I see that they're just totally ignoring or not even considering it and I speak, it's really a bad look.

[Ruseau]: It's a very bad look.

[Ruseau]: And I think we can't

[Ruseau]: We can't insert ourselves into the ordinance making process.

[Ruseau]: We can't tell them we want to see it before they approve it.

[Ruseau]: I also have watched how ordinances are made.

[Ruseau]: And aside from being, well, taking an enormous amount of time, by the time they are done with an ordinance to the point where they would pass it to us, if they wanted to, by the way, because we can't ask them, demand it, you know, the cake is made.

[Ruseau]: So, I mean, I know that in the last two or three years, there's been, I don't remember which ordinance it was, the one that keeps timing out and has to start over.

[Ruseau]: So I guess I'm just like, what is the, as complicated as it is, and I have looked at the language right now, and it is complicated, I think it seems like it would be far worse for us to wait for them to pass the ordinance and then

[Ruseau]: what let students and parents sue the city for violating FERPA, I mean, or whatever other laws are appropriate.

[Ruseau]: It just seems to me that not having our fingers in this, I keep using pie and I'm terrible with these analogies, but having at least a voice there to say, you know, the current language says nothing about when you walk into the schools, is there any difference?

[Ruseau]: And there is a difference and that's a fact.

[Ruseau]: So I just think it seems it behooves us to not wait till it's over.

[Ruseau]: And I also think it's really, I'm not interested in going to this meeting as a member of the public because I don't think I can speak as a member of the public.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: I have not been on city council mayor and I know you have, I guess my question is what if you pass and if the city council passes an ordinance that is clearly a violation of law.

[Ruseau]: I don't know who's who's who's who's who.

[Ruseau]: You know, how do we respond, I know I'm not interested in how I spend my Wednesday evening I'm interested in not having.

[Ruseau]: body worn cameras in our schools recording students without permission, we go through an absurd number of hoops to make sure we don't accidentally take a picture of a kid.

[Ruseau]: I mean, it's sort of like amazing that we don't screw that up more because frankly, it's so like, you know, there'll be a whole class and there'll be one kid who's the no picture kid and that's fine, that's great.

[Ruseau]: But we somehow manage that.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, does the ordinance say anything about when you walk onto school property, you turn the camera off?

[Ruseau]: Or does the data go to the same place in the sky as it would when you're not on school property?

[Ruseau]: I don't know, it just seems to me like we're just...

[Ruseau]: leaving it all out there and hoping for the best.

[Ruseau]: And I just, it doesn't feel responsible for me as a school committee member.

[Ruseau]: And obviously if the majority of the members feel it's more responsible to just hope that the city council does the right thing and hope that the right kinds of lawyers take a look at this before it gets approved, then that's up to the committee.

[Ruseau]: I mean, as I said, not like I really want to spend my Wednesday night doing this.

[Ruseau]: I made a point about disagreeing that we could act as members of the public and I guess I should have been more clear, certainly I have no trouble sending in commentary to the city council when they're drafting ordinance or making a decision about parking or the budget.

[Ruseau]: Or, you know, anything that's not related to schools, the moments it's related to schools, I just think it is, it's really a stretch to believe that we are not seen as school committee members when we're making our comments.

[Ruseau]: So, in that regard, I think.

[Ruseau]: You know, as individuals I think we're all welcome to write our letters, I think a letter is different than than participating and trying to have a voice at such a meeting.

[Ruseau]: I certainly am happy to write a letter to each of the city Councilors and you know, remind them that school law is not the same as just regular law and that they, I hope that they will take the time to consider it I mean, they may be watching this meeting but.

[Ruseau]: I guess I, my biggest concern is that, considering how long it takes to write an ordinance considering the complexity of this and many other ordinances, knowing that they got it right before

[Ruseau]: it's approved and ends up in muni code.

[Ruseau]: Just, it just seems reasonable I mean I know we, we actually have the City Council has a joint education subcommittee with the school committee that I don't know that has, I don't know when that's met, probably not since the new buildings for the middle and elementary schools, and I think other communities do have a joint

[Ruseau]: I don't think it's a subcommittee, whatever.

[Ruseau]: It's some kind of joint meeting between the city council and the school committee and this seems like the situation where that kind of thing would be very appropriate to discuss it but we don't have those at this time so it feels like, you know, that's in our potential rules if we get to keep that part that we will do something like that.

[Ruseau]: So, it, you know, considering that so many

[Ruseau]: it's clear there's a reason, like nobody wants just more meetings, but there are some times when the city council and the school committee really do have to have an interaction, an official interaction, not just a memo to the people you know or something.

[Ruseau]: So, I mean, if there's, we can just vote this down, I can withdraw it.

[Ruseau]: It sounds like there's not support.

[Ruseau]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: So thank you, Mayor Graham.

[Ruseau]: So I just wanted to read a little statement I had drafted around this.

[Ruseau]: So last Thursday, March 3rd, Senate Bill 1445 was unanimously passed by the Massachusetts Senate.

[Ruseau]: The bill, an act to increase access to disposable menstrual products in prisons, homeless shelters, and public schools is the culmination of a lot of work by a lot of people.

[Ruseau]: And it is important to mention the names of these people right here in Medford.

[Ruseau]: From 2016 to 2018 Maya Gomez and will address school created the free the pad project as part of the Center for citizenship and social responsibility from 2019 to 2020 Christina saying and Elizabeth hunt.

[Ruseau]: continued and expanded this work with their Tax Less Tampons Free Feminine Products project, also as part of the CCSR.

[Ruseau]: And now Malina McGovern and Mariana Constantara are continuing this important work with their project as part of the CCSR.

[Ruseau]: I want to thank Maya, Willa, Christina, Elizabeth, Malina, and Mariana.

[Ruseau]: for all they've done to make sure that this doesn't, that this stays an issue that we keep talking about.

[Ruseau]: And I'm very excited that the state house is doing something about it.

[Ruseau]: The lead sponsor of the Senate bill is none other than our own Senator Pat Jalen of, well, she lives in Somerville, but she's our Medford Senator.

[Ruseau]: And I wanna thank Pat for all of her hard work on getting this to the floor of the Senate and getting it voted.

[Ruseau]: And it was unanimously approved.

[Ruseau]: There are two lead sponsors in the House, our own Christine Barber and also Representative Jay Livingstone of Boston.

[Ruseau]: I want to thank Christine and Jay for all of their hard work and all the work that is definitely to come as they attempt to marshal this into becoming law through the House of Representatives.

[Ruseau]: I also want to thank the CCSR and their benefactors who ensure that the resources are available so our students can become the leaders that we know that they can be.

[Ruseau]: And finally, I want to thank the leadership of the Massachusetts menstrual equity coalition in the Massachusetts chapter of the National Organization of Women for their sustained work, which is needed to keep this important effort moving forward.

[Ruseau]: Yes.

[Ruseau]: Yes.

[Ruseau]: Yes.

[Ruseau]: I think that the mayor and the superintendent, as I've often spoken about how I

[Ruseau]: I also recognize that when we're having workshops, meetings, et cetera, that scheduling and figuring out the agenda, which is normal for the mayor as the agenda setter in our policies, or it's the standard one, that they meet and they actually talk and this happens.

[Ruseau]: this regular meeting of like, how's the agenda looking?

[Ruseau]: This is not a public meeting this is a meeting in public, a critically important distinction.

[Ruseau]: And it is drilled into us at MSC.

[Ruseau]: For a reason.

[Ruseau]: The superintendent, and all the staff that come to these meetings, it is not like the city council.

[Ruseau]: So this is an update to our policy BDB.

[Ruseau]: Last year, we made some major renovations as an understatement to this policy, and I certainly saw that our renovations last year were a

[Ruseau]: First, very good step.

[Ruseau]: This is a step to offer us the ability to do what City Council does and what all legislative bodies do, and that is that all motions and resolutions put forth by the members

[Ruseau]: get an actual number, so that instead of us talking about that thing we did that month ago and without having a number attached to it, it's challenging to talk about, but more importantly than how hard it is to talk about,

[Ruseau]: it is really difficult to track, to track things that we send a subcommittee to track reports we've asked for, and they just become this big blob of things that hopefully can be taken care of.

[Ruseau]: And so this change would actually add,

[Ruseau]: the numbering system, and the numbering system that is proposed here matches the one that city council uses.

[Ruseau]: I just thought it was important that we, within the city of Medford, have some consistency.

[Ruseau]: So it would be the year, and it's the calendar year, and then a number, and the number is assigned by the superintendent's office as they receive motions and resolutions from members.

[Ruseau]: and it's not really the most complicated thing.

[Ruseau]: You would not know your number, but you would send in a request to get on the agenda, and a superintendent's executive assistant would reply, and instead of saying it's on the agenda, would also tell us what the number is for our own records.

[Ruseau]: And...

[Ruseau]: I included some examples because I personally find examples to be very helpful.

[Ruseau]: It also includes a slight change to the format as it will appear on the agenda, but it is

[Ruseau]: and there's an additional piece of information, two pieces of information.

[Ruseau]: One is the meeting date requested and the submitted date.

[Ruseau]: So you may recall in December, I had two motions related to discipline that appeared at a very inopportune time on the agenda, even though I had submitted them weeks ahead of time.

[Ruseau]: So this just allows for clarification for when the member submitted it.

[Ruseau]: and when the member expected it to be on the agenda.

[Ruseau]: This whole members may, it's, oh, I didn't put the full language, I apologize, but it says the four members shall constitute a quorum, oh, but a smaller number may meet and adjourn from day to day.

[Ruseau]: No, actually, three members, if they're a part of a subcommittee, is a quorum.

[Ruseau]: So I don't know.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Three members who are not part of a subcommittee actually cannot adjourn.

[Ruseau]: This language doesn't exist at MASC anymore, and I suspect it is from the days before meeting law when, well, things were.

[Ruseau]: very different.

[Ruseau]: But there's no way for three members who are not part of a subcommittee to get together from time to time and adjourn because you can't have met.

[Ruseau]: There's no internal consistency to the policy or sentence.

[Ruseau]: I just noticed it when I was looking for the word quorum.

[Ruseau]: So it's non-existent policy anywhere else.

[Ruseau]: I think that practice is certainly organic, and the policy should be black and white, printed, well, in our manual, and enforceable.

[Ruseau]: She needs to know in black and white what we said is our policy.

[Ruseau]: And if we don't, then it's up to her

[Ruseau]: and we can't come back and say, you didn't enforce the policy.

[Ruseau]: I mean, we had a conversation here last year about the out-of-school suspension.

[Ruseau]: And I had made a comment that was rebuffed by the assistant superintendent and probably the superintendent, I can't remember the details.

[Ruseau]: And they were right, where I said, well, I'm sure if things are really bad, like somebody commits a murder, our policy doesn't have to take that into account.

[Ruseau]: The superintendent will just do what she should do.

[Ruseau]: And the point that they made was, that was made was that we should not be passing policy that intends for it to be violated in certain circumstances.

[Ruseau]: That's just not, that's like a, you know, this isn't law, but you know, it'd be like passing a law that expects people to just break the law when it's appropriate or inconvenient.

[Ruseau]: So I don't disagree that practice is certainly organic and practice should,

[Ruseau]: When practice is changing, policy should be changed, but what policy is absolutely, in my mind, 100% not organic.

[Ruseau]: Policy can certainly be written to be vague, where it can't be too detailed.

[Ruseau]: Sometimes there's just no way to be as explicit as we perhaps would like.

[Ruseau]: An example is the out-of-school suspension policy, where we left that except where

[Ruseau]: The law requires, for instance, a suspension or expulsion or whatever we said.

[Ruseau]: So, you know, we didn't go into the gory details.

[Ruseau]: We sort of left a vague sentence that covered our bases.

[Ruseau]: But I think that policy is absolutely not organic.

[Ruseau]: It's on paper, and that's our job.

[Ruseau]: It's our number one job, is to, if practice is not matching policy, and we like practice,

[Ruseau]: It is our responsibility as a legislative body to write a motion, to change the policy, to match what we want it to.

[Ruseau]: It is not to say, well, that's not what really happens, and just move along.

[Ruseau]: I mean, that's why we have probably hundreds of policies that are out of date.

[Ruseau]: So I'll start with just my remarks.

[Ruseau]: So joining a school committee is quite an experience.

[Ruseau]: My very first term within a couple of weeks, we had a crisis, which at the time everybody said, once you've been through this, you're gonna be good.

[Ruseau]: And then apparently that was a lie.

[Ruseau]: made me feel very much like just so comfortable.

[Ruseau]: She was so calm, I think Mr. Kuchar had mentioned that calmness is a feature, actually several people have probably mentioned that.

[Ruseau]: And I think that calmness came from experience, I assume.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, when I think about what Paulette brought to the school committee, although for a couple more hours, I think about how the context of how we, you know, how we got where we are today.

[Ruseau]: Having that historical knowledge, I assume helps her become, and it certainly provides calmness to me and I believe my colleagues, when we're facing things that are new to us.

[Ruseau]: My first question is, well, what does Paulette know about this?

[Ruseau]: Because I assume you know.

[Ruseau]: a lot about a lot of the things that we have faced, although I'm not sure you've been through a pandemic before.

[Ruseau]: So I just wanna say, I greatly appreciate your historical knowledge and the fact that your context gives you this calmness.

[Ruseau]: I don't know if you, maybe you were calm before you joined the school committee.

[Ruseau]: How would I know?

[Ruseau]: But it's definitely something that changes the air and I'm going to miss that greatly.

[Ruseau]: I am still probably going to call you every time I'm like, how did we get where we are today?

[Ruseau]: Because most of us now will not actually have answers to that question.

[Ruseau]: So we can't just Google, how did we get here?

[Ruseau]: You said a small number of students, but wouldn't all remote ninth graders last year have not taken the paper-based MCAS?

[Ruseau]: Oh, some did?

[Ruseau]: Yes.

[Ruseau]: I certainly remember that.
