[Ruseau]: So I really do think the committee should have to approve turning it off.

[Ruseau]: And if you come to us and say we need to turn it off because we're running a deficit of $10,000 a week or whatever, I think the committee should be the folks to say we can't afford it.

[Ruseau]: We aren't going to make up the money from somewhere else or whatever.

[Ruseau]: Motion to take a paper out of order, ma'am.

[Ruseau]: Mr. Russo.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Thank you for this work.

[Ruseau]: And I know it's a lot of work.

[Ruseau]: I do want to say that the word proactive is becoming a bit offensive.

[Ruseau]: As a parent of a seventh grader who can barely read, it's not proactive.

[Ruseau]: We're decades behind.

[Ruseau]: And so we're proactive because we have the law coming down.

[Ruseau]: We are not proactive to all these kids that can't read in our district.

[Ruseau]: While there's lots of new evidence, the evidence has, for the most part, been very clear for decades.

[Ruseau]: And we refuse to teach phonics because it's boring and teachers don't want to be bored.

[Ruseau]: The reading wars were lost, and the teachers just decided to rebrand it, rather than teaching phonics.

[Ruseau]: That's the truth.

[Ruseau]: So my question is, after doing all this, these teachers are going to have to teach phonics.

[Ruseau]: What are we going to do with the teachers that refuse?

[Ruseau]: Because there are going to be teachers refusing to teach it, because it's boring.

[Ruseau]: I know it's boring.

[Ruseau]: But it's not up to the teachers to decide that it's boring, and they're going to do it for two days a year and call that phonics.

[Ruseau]: So what are we going to do as a district when the teachers won't do it?

[Ruseau]: Because it's been, what, was it 1993 or 4 when this was decided by Congress because the teachers just couldn't work it out?

[Ruseau]: It's not going to be an option.

[Ruseau]: I'm not talking about the screener.

[Ruseau]: I mean, I didn't need the screeners to know that my four-year-old wasn't going to be able to read when he got to kindergarten.

[Ruseau]: I didn't need that.

[Ruseau]: He could remember the book.

[Ruseau]: That's why he could read.

[Ruseau]: But he could never actually read.

[Ruseau]: And his kindergarten teacher sort of made the inappropriate, not following the rules, said, you should get a neuropsych.

[Ruseau]: We don't typically do it until first or second grade.

[Ruseau]: But whispered in my ear that it should be done.

[Ruseau]: I'm glad she did, but the school's first time deciding he should get a neuropsych was second grade, I think, second or third.

[Ruseau]: My point is just figuring out which kids need services is one thing, but if the staff is incapable or disinterested or not up to par to do it,

[Ruseau]: Because what I've heard about phonics is it is so damn boring.

[Ruseau]: My son complains when he comes home because he has phonics and he loves his phonics teacher.

[Ruseau]: But he's like, oh, it's so boring.

[Ruseau]: And I wouldn't want to teach it day in and day out to a classroom full of kids who are bored.

[Ruseau]: I get it.

[Ruseau]: But it needs to not be a choice.

[Ruseau]: Yeah, and I just want to say, I also respect that my understanding is virtually no teaching schools actually teach this to the teachers anymore.

[Ruseau]: So, like, for the teachers, like, they need to be really taught how to do it from scratch, it sounds like, for a lot of teachers.

[Ruseau]: So, I mean, I don't mean to suggest that it's, like, just some simple thing they don't want to do and let those kids fail, but... They need to be supported as well.

[Ruseau]: Ongoing, really.

[Ruseau]: Right, right, of course.

[Ruseau]: Yeah, I understand.

[Ruseau]: Yes, so I realize we are going to

[Ruseau]: wait until we get a better cost analysis.

[Ruseau]: But regardless of which screener we end up going with, the interventions are no different.

[Ruseau]: And those are the actually really expensive thing.

[Ruseau]: So, I mean, $7 per student sounds like a lot more than $1 per student, but there's 300 kindergartners.

[Ruseau]: It's not, I mean, not that much money, although I realize professional development may make that number look tiny.

[Ruseau]: But these numbers per student,

[Ruseau]: per year or per time they're assessed?

[Ruseau]: Because I know a lot of tests are done.

[Ruseau]: So it's not like we sink the money and we could use it forever.

[Ruseau]: It's every year.

[Ruseau]: One shot.

[Ruseau]: All right.

[Ruseau]: Thank you.

[Ruseau]: Van der Kloot.

[Ruseau]: So, I mean, thinking back to when we passed the policy around the registration of organizations, one of the things that I think is part of what Member DiVenedetto was trying to get at is, you know, we lack a single scheduling system for the district's properties.

[Ruseau]: And so, therefore, we don't know if some group is using a room, are they paying market rate that we have set, or are they getting a, my buddy let me register the room because I know them, or are they actually a club at the school and we're not going to charge them.

[Ruseau]: So, you know, like all of our properties, every single one of the rooms and spaces that are being used by somebody

[Ruseau]: clubs, 501C3s, community schools, any sports teams that's not on any of these lists.

[Ruseau]: Who's the contact?

[Ruseau]: What are they paying, if anything?

[Ruseau]: They seem to be completely available and free.

[Ruseau]: in order to lower class size, increase after-school capacity, and to fund recruitment of permanent substitutes for all schools.

[Ruseau]: And the substitute pay, that's the end quote.

[Ruseau]: And I know that in some communities, or maybe even many or most communities, substitute pay is actually part of a contract.

[Ruseau]: In Medford, it isn't.

[Ruseau]: So I think that that is,

[Ruseau]: both good and bad, if it was in a contract, maybe it would be higher already, but because it's not, we can actually be, if we can secure more funding and we can target it that way, we can increase our substitute pay to whatever we want, well, assuming we can find the money, to really solve what is a crisis, I think, in some places where there's just no substitutes.

[Ruseau]: And, you know, whether it's a pay problem or not,

[Ruseau]: I mean, you know, the way our lives are created and oriented nowadays and the cost to live in Medford and all the other things makes it hard to find people for sure.

[Ruseau]: But when there are some number of people doing this work and they have choices, Medford at one rate and then one town over, you know.

[Ruseau]: 100 yards away for dramatically more money, it's kind of hard for anybody to rationally choose the worst pay.

[Ruseau]: So that's my motion.

[Ruseau]: I'm happy to repeat it.
